meanings.english: An attempt or opportunity to do something.
meanings.hindi: कुछ करने का अवसर या प्रयास।

content.usage: He failed the exam, but he will get another bite at the cherry next year.

extras.mnemonic: Imagine a cherry being a prize; taking a 'bite' is taking a chance to get it.
extras.origin: Imagine cherries are rare treats. Usually, you eat one whole. Getting a 'bite' means you got a lucky, small chance at something good. Historically, this relates to grabbing a small opportunity before it's gone forever.

meanings.english: An animal (or person) that carries heavy luggage or work.
meanings.hindi: बोझा ढोने वाला जानवर (या अत्यधिक काम करने वाला व्यक्ति)।

content.usage: Donkeys have served as beasts of burden for thousands of years.

extras.mnemonic: A 'beast' that bears a 'burden' (load).
extras.origin: Think of animals like donkeys or camels that carry heavy loads. A 'beast' carrying a 'burden' became a metaphor for anyone doing hard, thankless labor, often treated more like a work animal than a person.

meanings.english: A market where prices are rising, encouraging buying.
meanings.hindi: तेज़ी का बाज़ार (शेयर बाजार में बढ़ती कीमतें)।

content.usage: Investors made significant profits during the long bull market.

extras.mnemonic: Bulls attack by thrusting their horns UP; hence, the market goes UP.
extras.origin: Bulls attack by thrusting their horns UP, symbolizing rising prices. This contrasts with bears, which swipe their paws DOWN, symbolizing falling prices. These terms have been used in stock markets since the early 18th century.

meanings.english: A complicated situation; a problem that causes more trouble when you try to fix it.
meanings.hindi: एक जटिल समस्या जिसे छेड़ने पर और मुसीबतें खड़ी हो जाएं।

content.usage: Investigating the corruption scandal opened a real can of worms for the government.

extras.mnemonic: If you open a sealed can full of worms, they all wiggle out and make a mess that is hard to put back.
extras.origin: Fishermen used to carry worms in sealed cans. If you opened one, the worms would wiggle out in a messy, uncontrollable tangle. Now, it means starting a problem that is messy and hard to stop.

meanings.english: A fresh start; a situation where past mistakes are forgiven or forgotten.
meanings.hindi: नई शुरुआत / पिछली गलतियों को भुला देना।

content.usage: Moving to a new city gave him a clean slate to start his career.

extras.mnemonic: Think of an old chalkboard (slate) wiped clean so you can write something new.
extras.origin: In old schools and taverns, debts and scores were written on slate chalkboards. Wiping the slate clean meant erasing all past debts or mistakes, allowing a completely fresh start without any history.

meanings.english: A small, seemingly unimportant member of a large organization.
meanings.hindi: बड़ी मशीन का छोटा पुर्जा (महत्वहीन महसूस करना)।

content.usage: He felt like just another cog in the machine at the giant corporation.

extras.mnemonic: A cog is a small tooth on a gear; essential for movement but individually unnoticed.
extras.origin: A cog is a tiny tooth on a giant gear. It’s essential for the machine to move, but individually, it looks small and insignificant. This phrase reflects the feeling of being just a tiny part of a huge corporate machine.

meanings.english: Someone who seems unfriendly and does not share feelings.

content.usage: I tried to be nice to her, but she's a bit of a cold fish.

extras.mnemonic: Fish are cold-blooded and slippery to touch; implies a person lacking warmth.
extras.origin: Fish are cold-blooded and feel slippery and cool to the touch. Shakespeare used this term to describe someone who lacks warmth or emotion, just like a dead or cold fish feels in your hand.

meanings.english: An unwelcome intruder.

content.usage: The new manager was seen as a cuckoo in the nest by the established team.

extras.mnemonic: Cuckoo birds lay their eggs in other birds' nests; they are intruders.
extras.origin: The Cuckoo bird is a lazy mother; she lays her eggs in other birds' nests. The baby cuckoo then kicks out the other eggs. So, a 'cuckoo in the nest' is an intruder who takes over a place where they don't belong.

meanings.english: A situation or event which is much less impressive than expected.
meanings.hindi: ऊँची दुकान फीका पकवान / निराशाजनक परिणाम।

content.usage: The highly anticipated movie turned out to be a damp squib.

extras.mnemonic: A 'squib' is a small firecracker; if it is damp (wet), it won't explode.
extras.origin: A 'squib' was a small explosive used in mining. If it got damp, it wouldn't explode properly—it would just fizzle out. So, a damp squib is something that was supposed to be exciting but failed miserably.

meanings.english: A law or agreement that is no longer enforced or followed.

content.usage: The old treaty became a dead letter after the war broke out.

extras.mnemonic: A letter that cannot be delivered and cannot be returned is 'dead'; similarly, a law with no effect.
extras.origin: In the postal service, a 'dead letter' is mail that can't be delivered or returned—it has nowhere to go. Metaphorically, a law that exists but is ignored by everyone is just like that undeliverable letter.

meanings.english: Completely useless; a person or thing that is not helpful.

content.usage: The new computer system is a dead loss; it crashes every hour.

extras.mnemonic: Dead = no life/use; Loss = negative value.
extras.origin: Originally a maritime insurance term. If a cargo was lost completely with no chance of recovery, it was a 'dead loss'. Now it means anything or anyone that is completely useless or a total failure.

meanings.english: Someone with potential but lacking training or polish.
meanings.hindi: प्रतिभाशाली लेकिन अभी तराशा न गया हो / गुदड़ी का लाल।

content.usage: He looks messy, but as a singer, he is a diamond in the rough.

extras.mnemonic: Uncut diamonds look like rough stones until they are polished.
extras.origin: Natural diamonds look like dull, rough stones when found. You have to cut and polish them to see their sparkle. This describes a person who has great inner talent but lacks social polish or training.

meanings.english: Very common and of no particular value.

content.usage: Adventure novels are a dime a dozen these days.

extras.mnemonic: If you can get 12 (a dozen) for just a dime (10 cents), they must be cheap and common.
extras.origin: In the 1800s, goods were often sold for a dime (10 cents). If you could get twelve items for just one dime, they were very cheap and common. Hence, something that is everywhere and has low value.

meanings.english: A rehearsal or practice session.

content.usage: We need a dry run of the ceremony before the actual event.

extras.mnemonic: A fire hose practice without water is 'dry'; similarly, practice without the real pressure.
extras.origin: Firefighters used to practice drills without pumping water (dry) to save resources. It was a 'dry run'—a practice without the real mess. Now it means any rehearsal before the main event.

meanings.english: An unpleasant or messy situation (often used ironically).

content.usage: The car broke down in the rain; that's a fine state of affairs!

extras.mnemonic: Irony: calling a bad state 'fine'.
extras.origin: This is purely ironic. You look at a mess—like a broken car in the rain—and say, 'Well, this is a fine state!' The British love using 'fine' to mean the exact opposite when annoyed.

meanings.english: Strong ambition, energy, and enthusiasm.
meanings.hindi: जोश और उत्साह / कुछ करने की ललक।

content.usage: She has a fire in her belly to become the best athlete in the country.

extras.mnemonic: Fire implies energy/heat; in the belly implies deep internal drive.
extras.origin: The belly is seen as the center of hunger and instinct. Having a 'fire' there implies a burning, consuming drive to achieve something. It’s not just a wish; it’s a visceral, physical need to succeed.

meanings.english: An unperceived observer who hears/sees things without being noticed.
meanings.hindi: चुपके से देखने वाला / गुप्त प्रेक्षक।

content.usage: I wish I could be a fly on the wall during their secret meeting.

extras.mnemonic: A fly is small and unnoticed on a wall, yet present in the room.
extras.origin: Imagine being a tiny fly on a wall. You can see and hear everything in the room, but nobody notices you. It’s the perfect position for a spy or someone who wants to know secrets.

meanings.english: Happiness based on ignorance or not knowing about potential trouble.
meanings.hindi: हवाई महल / मूखर् की स्वर्ग (सच्चाई से अनजान होकर खुश रहना)।

content.usage: They are living in a fool's paradise if they think the market won't crash.

extras.mnemonic: Only a fool feels like he is in paradise when danger is near.
extras.origin: A fool believes he is safe and happy even when danger is all around. It refers to a state of happiness based entirely on ignorance or delusion—a paradise that only a fool could believe in.

meanings.english: A man without a job; a person who is free and not confined.

content.usage: Since losing his position, he has been a gentleman at large.

extras.mnemonic: 'At large' usually means free (like a criminal at large), here applied to a gentleman with no duties.
extras.origin: In Old English, 'at large' meant free to roam, like a prisoner who escaped. A 'gentleman at large' was someone with no specific duties or job, free to wander around, often implying he was unemployed.

meanings.english: The prudent middle course between two extremes.

content.usage: He tried to find a golden mean between spending too much and being a miser.

extras.mnemonic: Golden = valuable/perfect; Mean = average/middle.
extras.origin: Ancient Greek philosophy, especially Aristotle, taught that virtue lies in the middle. Courage is the 'golden mean' between cowardice and recklessness. It’s the perfect, valuable middle path.

meanings.english: An unclear situation not easily categorized as right or wrong.

content.usage: The laws regarding digital copyright are still a grey area.

extras.mnemonic: Grey is between Black and White; hence, neither clearly one nor the other.
extras.origin: Black and white are clear opposites. Grey is the messy mix in between. A 'grey area' is a situation where rules aren't clear, and you can't easily say what is right or wrong.

meanings.english: A challenging or awkward situation; a flaw.

content.usage: The arrival of the ex-husband was a hair in the butter at the wedding.

extras.mnemonic: Nobody wants to find a hair in their smooth butter; it spoils the experience.
extras.origin: Butter should be smooth and pure. Finding a hair in it is disgusting and ruins the meal. It refers to a small, annoying detail that spoils something otherwise good or creates an awkward situation.

meanings.english: An object of laughter or ridicule.

content.usage: His silly mistake made him the laughing stock of the class.

extras.mnemonic: Stock = a supply; you become the supply/source of everyone's laughter.
extras.origin: A 'stock' was a stump or butt of a joke. If you became the 'laughing stock', you were the supply or source of everyone's laughter, like a clown or a fool on display.

meanings.english: An ambiguous compliment that is actually insulting.

content.usage: She said I look 'healthy', which felt like a left-handed compliment implying I gained weight.

extras.mnemonic: Left hand was historically associated with clumsiness or insincerity.
extras.origin: Historically, the left side (sinister) was seen as unlucky or insincere. A compliment given with the 'left hand' was considered clumsy or fake, often hiding an insult inside praise.

content.phrase: A leopard can't change its spots

meanings.english: It is impossible for one to change one's essential character.

content.usage: I doubt he will stop lying; a leopard can't change its spots.

extras.mnemonic: You can't wash the spots off a leopard; they are part of who it is.
extras.origin: From the Bible (Jeremiah 13:23): 'Can the Ethiopian change his skin, or the leopard his spots?' It emphasizes that innate nature is permanent—you can't wash away what you are born with.

meanings.english: A sudden, brief feeling of friendliness or thankfulness.

content.usage: He felt a little gush of gratitude when the stranger held the door for him.

extras.mnemonic: Gush = sudden flow; a sudden flow of 'thank you' feelings.
extras.origin: A 'gush' is a sudden flow of liquid. This describes a sudden, warm feeling of thankfulness that bubbles up inside you, often fleeting but intense.

meanings.english: Having many responsibilities or problems to deal with.

content.usage: I can't take on new work right now; I have a lot on my plate.

extras.mnemonic: Imagine a dinner plate piled so high with food you can't finish it.
extras.origin: Imagine you are at a buffet and your plate is piled high with food. You have to eat it all. Metaphorically, you have so many tasks or problems (food) to deal with that you can't take anymore.

meanings.english: A very courageous and energetic man.

content.usage: He fought for his rights like a man of spirit.

extras.mnemonic: Spirit = soul/energy/courage.
extras.origin: In older English, 'spirit' meant vital energy or courage. A 'man of spirit' wasn't a ghost, but someone full of life, energy, and the courage to stand up for himself.

meanings.english: A discovery that turns out to be false; a complex or confused situation.

content.usage: The scientist's claim turned out to be a mare's nest; the data was all wrong.

extras.mnemonic: Mares (female horses) don't build nests. If you find one, it's fake or an illusion.
extras.origin: Horses (mares) don't build nests; birds do. So if someone claims to have found a 'mare's nest', they have found something impossible or fake—a complex illusion or a false discovery.

meanings.english: A foolish person (Note: Can be offensive/slur in some contexts, use with caution).

content.usage: Don't be such a nig nog and put your coat on.

extras.mnemonic: Sounds like a nonsense word for a silly person.
extras.origin: A slang term, possibly derived from 'niggler' (a trifler) or simply a nonsense sound like 'ning-nong'. It usually describes someone acting foolishly or clumsily, though its use can be offensive today.

meanings.english: An endless job; a work that never finishes.
meanings.hindi: कभी न खत्म होने वाला काम।

content.usage: Cleaning this huge house feels like a Penelope's web.

extras.mnemonic: Penelope wove a shroud by day and unraveled it by night to delay marriage.
extras.origin: In Greek myth, Penelope waited for Odysseus. To delay remarriage, she wove a shroud by day and unraveled it by night. Her work never finished. It refers to an endless task.

meanings.english: A way of asking what someone is thinking.

content.usage: You've been quiet for an hour. A penny for your thoughts?

extras.mnemonic: Offering a small payment (penny) to buy the secret thoughts of someone.
extras.origin: In the 1500s, a penny was a decent sum. Offering a penny to buy someone's thoughts was a friendly way to ask a quiet person what they were thinking about.

meanings.english: A share in money, profits, or business.

content.usage: Everyone wants a piece of the pie when the company makes a profit.

extras.mnemonic: Pie represents the total wealth; a piece is your share.
extras.origin: Imagine a business profit is a delicious pie. Everyone involved wants a slice of it. It symbolizes sharing the wealth or benefits of a venture.

content.phrase: A red rag to a bull

meanings.english: An object or act which is certain to provoke someone.
meanings.hindi: सांड को लाल कपड़ा दिखाना / उकसाने वाला कार्य।

content.usage: Talking about politics at dinner is like a red rag to a bull for my father.

extras.mnemonic: Matadors use red capes to provoke bulls (though bulls are actually colorblind to red, the movement provokes them).
extras.origin: In bullfighting, matadors wave red capes. While bulls are actually colorblind to red, the waving cape provokes them to charge. It refers to anything that instantly makes someone angry.

meanings.english: A single bad person or thing in a group that spoils the rest.
meanings.hindi: एक गंदी मछली (जो सारे तालाब को गंदा कर दे)।

content.usage: Don't let one rotten apple ruin the team's spirit.

extras.mnemonic: One rotten apple releases gas that rots the others in the barrel.
extras.origin: One rotten apple releases gas that causes the other apples in the barrel to rot quickly. It’s a warning that one bad person can corrupt an entire group.

meanings.english: A person, custom, or institution considered too important to be criticized.
meanings.hindi: आलोचना से परे व्यक्ति या वस्तु।

content.usage: The healthcare budget is a sacred cow that no politician dares to cut.

extras.mnemonic: Cows are sacred in Hinduism and not to be harmed; metaphorically, things not to be touched/criticized.
extras.origin: In Hinduism, cows are revered and cannot be harmed. The British adopted this to describe any institution or person that is considered immune to criticism or change, no matter what.

meanings.english: A reliable and trustworthy person.

content.usage: We need a safe pair of hands to lead the project during this crisis.

extras.mnemonic: In sports (like cricket/soccer), a player who catches the ball safely is reliable.
extras.origin: From cricket or goalkeeping. If the ball is in a 'safe pair of hands', it won't be dropped. It refers to a person you can trust completely to handle a job without messing up.

meanings.english: A subject that makes someone feel angry or upset.

content.usage: Don't ask him about his divorce; it's a sore point with him.

extras.mnemonic: Touching a physical sore hurts; touching a 'sore point' in conversation hurts emotionally.
extras.origin: If you have a physical wound or sore, touching it hurts. A 'sore point' is a topic that hurts emotionally when mentioned, like a divorce or failure.

meanings.english: An obstinate, stubborn, or haughty person.

content.usage: He is too stiff-necked to admit he made a mistake.

extras.mnemonic: If your neck is stiff, you can't nod (agree) or bow (show humility).
extras.origin: In the Bible, people who refused to bow their heads to God were called 'stiff-necked'. If your neck is stiff, you can't nod or bow. It describes someone stubborn and arrogant.

meanings.english: Great outrage or excitement about a trivial matter.
meanings.hindi: तिल का ताड़ / छोटी बात का बतंगड़।

content.usage: Their argument was just a storm in a teacup; they were friends again by noon.

extras.mnemonic: A storm inside a tiny teacup is ridiculous and insignificant compared to a real ocean storm.
extras.origin: A storm is scary on the ocean, but inside a teacup, it's tiny and harmless. This mocks people who make a huge fuss over something incredibly small and insignificant.

meanings.english: A pompous, formal, and boring person.

content.usage: I expected the CEO to be a stuffed shirt, but he was actually quite funny.

extras.mnemonic: Imagine a shirt stuffed with straw (scarecrow) or padding; looks big/formal but has no substance/life inside.
extras.origin: Imagine a shirt stuffed with straw like a scarecrow. It looks like a person, but there's no real human inside. It describes a pompous, formal person who has no personality or warmth.

meanings.english: An obstacle or circumstance that causes difficulty or hesitation.

content.usage: Lack of funding is the main stumbling block for our project.

extras.mnemonic: A block on the road that makes you stumble (trip).
extras.origin: In the Bible, putting a stone in front of a blind person to make them trip was a sin. A 'stumbling block' is any obstacle or difficulty that trips up your progress.

meanings.english: A constant source of annoyance or trouble.
meanings.hindi: जी का जंजाल / लगातार परेशान करने वाला।

content.usage: That rebellious employee has been a thorn in the manager's flesh for years.

extras.mnemonic: A thorn stuck in your skin hurts constantly until removed.
extras.origin: St. Paul in the Bible described his ailment as 'a thorn in the flesh'—something small but constantly painful that you can't get rid of. It refers to a persistent annoyance.

meanings.english: A controversial or difficult problem.

content.usage: How to reduce taxes remains a vexed question for the parliament.

extras.mnemonic: Vex = to annoy/frustrate; A question that frustrates everyone.
extras.origin: To 'vex' means to annoy or frustrate. A 'vexed question' is a problem that has been debated for a long time with no solution, frustrating everyone involved.

meanings.english: A person's occupation or position within society.

content.usage: People from all walks of life attended the concert.

extras.mnemonic: The path (walk) you take in life (career/status).
extras.origin: Life is viewed as a journey or a path. People walk different paths depending on their job or status. 'All walks of life' means people from every different background and career.

meanings.english: A person who discourages enjoyment or enthusiasm.
meanings.hindi: कबाब में हड्डी / मज़ा किरकिरा करने वाला।

content.usage: Don't invite him to the party; he is such a wet blanket.

extras.mnemonic: A wet blanket is used to smother (put out) a fire; this person puts out the 'fire' of fun.
extras.origin: Before fire extinguishers, people threw wet blankets over fires to smother them. A person who is a 'wet blanket' smothers the fun and enthusiasm of a party just like that.

meanings.english: Pure water.

content.usage: He refused the wine and asked for a glass of Adam's ale.

extras.mnemonic: Adam (the first man) only had water to drink.
extras.origin: Adam, the first man in the Bible, had no wine or beer—only water to drink. So, 'Adam's ale' is a humorous, old-fashioned term for plain water.

meanings.english: Sharing one's own tastes or views.
meanings.hindi: अपने मनपसंद / अपनी ही तरह का।

content.usage: She loves reading as much as I do; she is a woman after my own heart.

extras.mnemonic: Someone designed according to your heart's desire.
extras.origin: Biblical origin: David was a man 'after God's own heart', meaning he shared God's values. If someone is after your own heart, they think and feel just like you do.

meanings.english: A wild guess or an attempt with little chance of success.

content.usage: I didn't know the answer, so it was just a shot in the dark.

extras.mnemonic: Shooting in the dark means you can't see the target and are just guessing.
extras.origin: If you shoot a gun in the dark, you can't see the target. You are just firing blindly and hoping to hit something. It refers to a guess made with zero information.

meanings.english: To help or encourage someone to commit a crime or wrong act.

content.usage: He was charged with aiding and abetting the robbery.

extras.mnemonic: Aid = Help; Abet = Encourage (usually in bad things).
extras.origin: Legal terms: 'Aid' means to help, and 'Abet' comes from a word meaning to bait or incite dogs. Together, they mean helping and encouraging someone to commit a crime.

meanings.english: In a state of great excitement or amazement.

content.usage: The children were all agog to see their presents.

extras.mnemonic: Agog sounds like 'goggles' - eyes wide open in amazement.
extras.origin: From the French 'en gogues', meaning in mirth or fun. It suggests being wide-eyed and eager, like a child waiting for a treat, full of excitement and curiosity.

meanings.english: Everyone is needed to help with a problem.

content.usage: It's a busy week, so it's all hands on deck at the office.

extras.mnemonic: On a ship, all sailors (hands) must come to the deck during a storm.
extras.origin: A naval command. When a storm hit or a battle began, every sailor ('hand') was needed on the deck to save the ship. Now it means everyone must help in a crisis.

meanings.english: One who talks big but lacks substance or action.
meanings.hindi: डींगें मारने वाला (जो काम कुछ न करे)।

content.usage: He talks about investing millions, but he's all hat and no cattle.

extras.mnemonic: A cowboy wearing a big hat but owning no cows is a fake cowboy.
extras.origin: A Texan insult. Imagine a cowboy dressed perfectly with a big hat but owning no cows. He looks the part but has no substance. It describes someone who talks big but achieves nothing.

meanings.english: Exhausted.

content.usage: After the marathon, I was absolutely all in.

extras.mnemonic: If you put 'all' your energy 'in', you have nothing left (exhausted).
extras.origin: In gambling (poker), putting 'all in' means betting everything you have. In physical terms, if you put all your energy in, you have nothing left—you are completely exhausted.

meanings.english: Part of a person's typical work; nothing unusual.

content.usage: Saving lives is just all in a day's work for a firefighter.

extras.mnemonic: It fits inside the daily routine, so it's normal.
extras.origin: For a specialist (like a surgeon or firefighter), dealing with crisis is just part of their daily routine. It dismisses a difficult task as normal and expected.

meanings.english: Far from reality; nonsense or concocted lies.

content.usage: His explanation for being late was all moonshine.

extras.mnemonic: Moonshine is an illusion (light is not real, it's reflected) or illegal alcohol (makes you talk nonsense).
extras.origin: Moonlight is an illusion—it's just reflected sun. Also, 'moonshine' (illegal liquor) makes people talk nonsense. So, 'all moonshine' means something is total nonsense or fantasy.

meanings.english: With full force or strength.
meanings.hindi: पूरे जोर-शोर से / पूरी ताकत से।

content.usage: We rowed the boat with all our might and main to reach the shore.

extras.mnemonic: Main means 'physical strength' (archaic); Might means power.
extras.origin: An old phrase using redundancy for effect. 'Main' meant physical strength (as in 'by main force'). Using 'might and main' implies using every bit of your spiritual and physical power.

meanings.english: Everywhere; all over the place.

content.usage: We looked all over hell's half acre for the missing keys.

extras.mnemonic: Hell is vast; searching half an acre of it implies a messy, wide search.
extras.origin: Hell is imagined as a vast, chaotic place. Searching even 'half an acre' of it implies a frantic, messy search everywhere. It’s a colorful way to say 'all over the place'.

meanings.english: Use of an abundance of abbreviations or acronyms.
meanings.hindi: संक्षिप्ताक्षरों की भरमार (जिसे समझना मुश्किल हो)।

content.usage: The technical manual was just alphabet soup to me.

extras.mnemonic: A soup with pasta letters is a jumble of letters; similarly, a text full of acronyms (FBI, CIA, NASA).
extras.origin: Based on the soup with pasta letters. A bowl of alphabet soup is a jumble of letters. It describes speech or text full of confusing acronyms (like NASA, FBI, ASAP) that make no sense.

content.phrase: Always a bridesmaid, never a bride

meanings.english: Someone who is never the most important person in a particular situation.
meanings.hindi: हमेशा दूसरे स्थान पर रहने वाला।

content.usage: He's been nominated for an Oscar five times but never won; always a bridesmaid, never a bride.

extras.mnemonic: Bridesmaids support the bride but don't get the glory of the wedding day.
extras.origin: From a mouthwash ad: 'Always a bridesmaid, never a bride'. The bridesmaid is close to the happy event but isn't the star. It refers to someone who never quite achieves the top spot.

meanings.english: A complete change of opinion or direction.
meanings.hindi: पूर्ण परिवर्तन / अपनी बात से पलट जाना।

content.usage: The government did an about turn on the tax policy.

extras.mnemonic: Military command 'About Turn' means to turn 180 degrees to face the opposite way.
extras.origin: A military drill command. Soldiers marching forward are ordered to 'About Turn', instantly reversing direction by 180 degrees. It means completely changing your opinion or policy.

meanings.english: One of a number of resources or strategies that can be used.

content.usage: Diplomacy is just one arrow in the quiver of foreign policy.

extras.mnemonic: A quiver holds arrows; having an arrow means you have a weapon/option ready.
extras.origin: In archery, a quiver holds your arrows. Having 'an arrow in the quiver' means you have a strategy or resource ready to use when needed.

meanings.english: A firmly held belief.

content.usage: For him, punctuality is an article of faith.

extras.mnemonic: Religious articles (rules) are believed without question.
extras.origin: Religious creeds are called Articles of Faith—truths you must believe without question. Metaphorically, it’s any belief you hold firmly and refuse to doubt.

meanings.english: A private, selfish reason for doing something.
meanings.hindi: अपना उल्लू सीधा करना / स्वार्थ सिद्ध करना।

content.usage: I think he helped us only because he has an axe to grind with the boss.

extras.mnemonic: If you use someone's grindstone to sharpen your own axe, you are using them for your benefit.
extras.origin: From a story by Benjamin Franklin about a man who flattered a boy to get him to turn a grindstone to sharpen his axe. Once the axe was sharp, he was rude. It means having a selfish motive.

meanings.english: Two unlike things that cannot be compared.

content.usage: Comparing his painting to a photograph is like comparing apples and oranges.

extras.mnemonic: You can't compare the taste of an apple to an orange; they are fundamentally different.
extras.origin: Apples and oranges are totally different fruits with different textures and tastes. You can't judge one by the standards of the other. It means two things are incomparable.

meanings.english: Extremely observant; vigilant.

content.usage: The teacher was Argus-eyed and caught the student cheating immediately.

extras.mnemonic: Argus was a giant with 100 eyes.
extras.origin: In Greek mythology, Argus Panoptes was a giant with 100 eyes. Even when sleeping, some eyes stayed open. He was the ultimate watchman. It means being incredibly vigilant.

meanings.english: Day and night; continuously (24 hours).

content.usage: Doctors worked around the clock to save the patient.

extras.mnemonic: The hands of the clock go all the way around (24 hours).
extras.origin: The hands of a clock go 'around' the dial endlessly. Working 'around the clock' means working 24 hours a day, or continuously without stopping.

meanings.english: Actually; as it happened.
meanings.hindi: सच तो यह है / वास्तव में।

content.usage: I am not angry. As a matter of fact, I am quite relieved.

extras.mnemonic: Relating to the 'fact' or truth of the matter.
extras.origin: Originally a legal phrase (Latin: *ad rem*), distinguishing what actually happened (fact) from what was supposed to happen. It emphasizes the truth.

meanings.english: Readily understood; very clear sound.
meanings.hindi: स्पष्ट रूप से समझ में आने वाला / सुस्पष्ट।

content.usage: Even over the phone, her voice was as clear as a bell.

extras.mnemonic: Bells are made of metal that rings with a pure, clear sound.
extras.origin: Bells are cast from special metal to ring with a pure, sharp sound. If a bell is cracked, it thuds. 'Clear as a bell' implies a sound or voice that is perfect and easy to hear.

meanings.english: Extremely silly.

content.usage: He is a nice guy, but as daft as a brush.

extras.mnemonic: A brush (broom) has no brain; acting like one is silly.
extras.origin: A brush (or broom) is an inanimate object with no brain. Comparing someone to a brush implies they are acting incredibly stupid or silly. A British colloquialism.

meanings.english: Strong and healthy.

content.usage: My grandfather is 90 but still as fit as a fiddle.

extras.mnemonic: Fiddles (violins) must be kept in perfect condition ('fit') to sound good.
extras.origin: In the 1600s, 'fit' meant suitable. A fiddle (violin) must be in perfect condition to sound right. Being 'fit as a fiddle' means your body is in perfect working order.

meanings.english: Emotionless; physically or mentally tough.

content.usage: The drill sergeant was as hard as nails.

extras.mnemonic: Nails are made of metal and are hard; a person like this shows no softness.
extras.origin: Iron nails are rigid and unyielding. A person described as 'hard as nails' has no softness or sentimentality—they are tough, unfeeling, and physically resilient.

meanings.english: Intoxicated with alcohol or drugs.

content.usage: He came home from the party as high as a kite.

extras.mnemonic: Kites fly high; being 'high' means being intoxicated.
extras.origin: Kites fly high in the sky. Being 'high' is slang for being intoxicated. So, floating in the sky like a kite describes someone completely out of it on drugs or alcohol.

meanings.english: The shortest route (straight line).

content.usage: The town is ten miles away as the crow flies, but twenty by road.

extras.mnemonic: Crows fly straight to their destination, ignoring roads and obstacles.
extras.origin: Roads wind around obstacles, but crows fly in a straight line from point A to point B. 'As the crow flies' is the shortest, direct distance between two places.

content.phrase: As thick as two short planks

meanings.english: Extremely stupid.

content.usage: He can't understand the simplest instructions; he's as thick as two short planks.

extras.mnemonic: Thick wood is dense; 'thick' also means stupid.
extras.origin: A short, thick plank of wood is dense and solid—you can't get through it. Describing a person this way suggests their head is made of solid wood: they are extremely stupid.

meanings.english: To pretend superiority; to boast about oneself.

content.usage: She started assuming airs after she got the promotion.

extras.mnemonic: Putting on 'airs' means acting lofty (up in the air) and superior.
extras.origin: From the French 'air', meaning manner. Putting on 'airs' means acting 'high and mighty'—pretending to be of a higher social class or better than you actually are.

meanings.english: Continuously without stopping.

content.usage: He can work for ten hours at a stretch.

extras.mnemonic: Stretching time without breaking it.
extras.origin: Imagine stretching a rubber band; it's one continuous piece. Working 'at a stretch' means doing it in one long, continuous session without taking a break.

meanings.english: Always ready to obey someone's orders.
meanings.hindi: इशारे पर नाचने वाला / सेवा में हाज़िर।

content.usage: She expects her assistant to be at her beck and call 24/7.

extras.mnemonic: Beck (beckon/signal) and Call; ready for both.
extras.origin: 'Beck' is short for beckon (a hand signal). If you are at someone's beck and call, you are ready to jump whenever they signal or call your name. Total servitude.

content.phrase: At the drop of a hat

meanings.english: Instantly; without any hesitation.

content.usage: He is ready to fight at the drop of a hat.

extras.mnemonic: In races, dropping a hat used to signal the start; so you start instantly.
extras.origin: In the 19th century, dropping a hat was often the signal to start a fight or a race. It meant action started instantly. Now, it means doing something immediately without hesitation.

meanings.english: Arguing or fighting angrily.
meanings.hindi: एक-दूसरे के खून का प्यासा / गुस्से में बहस करना।

content.usage: The two brothers are always at each other's throats.

extras.mnemonic: Like animals attacking the throat to kill; fighting fiercely.
extras.origin: Predators attack the throat to kill quickly. If two people are 'at each other's throats', they are fighting viciously, trying to destroy one another.

meanings.english: A criminal who has not been arrested yet; generally.
meanings.hindi: पुलिस की पकड़ से बाहर / मुक्त।

content.usage: The escaped prisoner is still at large.

extras.mnemonic: Large space = having lots of room to roam free.
extras.origin: From Old French 'au large', meaning having space. A prisoner 'at large' has the whole world to roam in—they aren't confined in a cell. It means free or uncaptured.

meanings.english: In strong disagreement or conflict.
meanings.hindi: शत्रुता की स्थिति में / ठनी होना।

content.usage: The management and the union are at loggerheads over pay.

extras.mnemonic: A loggerhead was a heavy iron tool; fighting with them would be brutal.
extras.origin: A 'loggerhead' was a heavy iron tool. In battles, sailors might fight with them. Being 'at loggerheads' means being locked in a stubborn, violent dispute.

meanings.english: Uncertain situation due to having nothing to do.
meanings.hindi: बेकार / जिसके पास करने को कुछ न हो।

content.usage: If you are at a loose end this weekend, come visit us.

extras.mnemonic: Like a rope with an untied end; dangling without purpose.
extras.origin: Nautical term. A rope with a loose, unattached end serves no purpose and dangles uselessly. Being 'at a loose end' means having no job or plan, just hanging around.

meanings.english: To be puzzled, perplexed, or confused because a problem is too difficult.

content.usage: I've tried everything to fix the car, and now I'm at my wit's end.

extras.mnemonic: Your 'wit' (intelligence) has reached its 'end' (limit).
extras.origin: Your 'wit' is your intelligence. If you travel to the very 'end' of your intelligence and still can't solve the problem, you are at your wit's end—panicked and confused.

meanings.english: In a state of total confusion or disorder.

content.usage: After the burglary, the whole house was at sixes and sevens.

extras.mnemonic: Numbers 6 and 7 are close but not aligned; implies disorder.
extras.origin: From an old dice game ('Hazard') where rolling a 6 and 7 was a difficult, risky situation. It came to represent general confusion, disorder, or a state of chaos.

meanings.english: Paid for by someone; or making fun of someone.
meanings.hindi: किसी के खर्च पर / किसी की कीमत पर।

content.usage: He told a joke at his wife's expense.

extras.mnemonic: Expense = cost; either money cost or emotional cost.
extras.origin: If you buy a meal, it's at your expense. Metaphorically, if a joke is told 'at your expense', you are paying the price for the laughter—you are the victim.

meanings.english: In danger; being risked.

content.usage: With the new policy, thousands of jobs are at stake.

extras.mnemonic: Gamblers place money at a 'stake' (post); if they lose, the stake is gone.
extras.origin: In gambling or bear-baiting, money was placed on a wooden post (stake). If you lost, the money on the stake was gone. Being 'at stake' means being at risk of being lost.

content.phrase: At the top of your lungs

meanings.english: Extremely loudly.

content.usage: He shouted at the top of his lungs to warn the pedestrians.

extras.mnemonic: Using all the air in your lungs to scream.
extras.origin: To scream loudly, you need to fill your lungs completely. Shouting from the 'top' of your lungs means using your full breath capacity to make maximum noise.

meanings.english: In disagreement with; opposite to.

content.usage: His lifestyle was at variance with his principles.

extras.mnemonic: Variance = Variation/Difference.
extras.origin: Statistical/Legal term. Variance measures difference. If two things are 'at variance', they do not match or agree—they are diverging from each other.

meanings.english: To produce a result that is balanced over a period of time.

content.usage: The highs and lows of the market tend to average out over the year.

extras.mnemonic: Mathematics: finding the middle value.
extras.origin: In math, an average smooths out extreme highs and lows. In life, 'averaging out' means that over time, good and bad luck balance each other, leading to a normal result.

meanings.english: A young defenseless person; an innocent or naive person.

content.usage: When it comes to politics, he is a babe in the woods.

extras.mnemonic: A baby lost in a forest is helpless and innocent.
extras.origin: From the old ballad 'The Children in the Wood', where two babes are abandoned in a forest and die. It describes someone innocent, inexperienced, and helpless in a dangerous world.

meanings.english: Resume duty; to return to work or an activity.

content.usage: After a long illness, he is finally back in the saddle.

extras.mnemonic: A cowboy getting back on his horse after falling or resting.
extras.origin: Cowboy idiom. If a cowboy falls off or gets sick, he can't work. Getting 'back in the saddle' means climbing back onto the horse to resume work and control.

meanings.english: Support.

content.usage: I need you to back me in this argument.

extras.mnemonic: Standing behind someone (at their back) gives them support.
extras.origin: In a fight, having someone stand at your back prevents enemies from attacking you from behind. 'Backing' someone means providing support and protection.

meanings.english: Withdraw from a commitment.
meanings.hindi: वादे से मुकर जाना / पीछे हटना।

content.usage: You promised to help; you can't back out of it now.

extras.mnemonic: Walking backwards out of a room/deal.
extras.origin: Imagine walking into a room to make a deal, then changing your mind and walking backwards out the door. It means withdrawing from a promise or situation.

meanings.english: Plan it all over again because the first attempt failed.
meanings.hindi: नए सिरे से बनाना / पुनः आरंभ करना।

content.usage: Our design failed the test, so it's back to the drawing board.

extras.mnemonic: Architects draw plans on a board; if the building fails, they go back to the board.
extras.origin: Architects draw blueprints on a board. If a building collapses or a design is rejected, they must go 'back to the drawing board' to start the plan all over again.

meanings.english: People of bad character.

content.usage: Stay away from him; he's a bad hat.

extras.mnemonic: In old movies, villains often wore specific 'bad' hats (black hats).
extras.origin: In early cowboy movies, villains often wore black hats and heroes wore white hats. A 'bad hat' is a rascal or someone with a bad character.

meanings.english: Nonsensical talk; insincere flattery.

content.usage: Don't give me that banana oil; tell me the truth.

extras.mnemonic: Bananas are slippery; oil is slippery; implies slippery/smooth but fake talk.
extras.origin: 1920s slang. Banana oil (amyl acetate) smells like artificial bananas. The phrase implies something that smells fake—nonsense or insincere flattery.

content.phrase: Bark is worse than his bite

meanings.english: Someone who seems aggressive/scary but is actually harmless.
meanings.hindi: जो गरजते हैं वो बरसते नहीं।

content.usage: The boss shouts a lot, but his bark is worse than his bite.

extras.mnemonic: A dog that barks loudly usually doesn't attack.
extras.origin: Dogs often bark loudly to scare threats away without actually attacking. A person whose 'bark is worse than his bite' sounds angry but isn't actually dangerous.

meanings.english: Prepare for a difficult situation.

content.usage: A recession is coming; companies need to batten down the hatches.

extras.mnemonic: On a ship, hatches (doors) are closed/battened to prevent water entry during a storm.
extras.origin: Nautical term. When a storm approaches, sailors fasten (batten) strips of wood over the covers of the ship's hatches to keep water out. It means preparing for trouble.

meanings.english: Make no difference; to be the same to someone.

content.usage: Whether we go by bus or train, it's all one to me.

extras.mnemonic: If multiple options are 'all one' (the same), it doesn't matter which you pick.
extras.origin: If two things are 'all one', they are identical. So, it doesn't matter which one happens—it makes no difference to you.

meanings.english: To be in serious trouble.

content.usage: If my parents find out I failed, I'm dead meat.

extras.mnemonic: Meat is lifeless; being 'dead meat' implies you are as good as finished.
extras.origin: If meat is dead, it is lifeless and ready to be cooked. Being 'dead meat' means you are in such big trouble that you are as good as finished.

meanings.english: Suffering from a disease or illness.
meanings.hindi: बीमार होना / किसी बीमारी से ग्रस्त।

content.usage: He is down with the flu and won't come to work today.

extras.mnemonic: When you are sick, you are often lying 'down' in bed.
extras.origin: When you are sick, you are usually lying 'down' in bed, incapacitated. Being 'down with' something means you have been laid low by illness.

meanings.english: To be talented and likely to become successful.
meanings.hindi: सफल होने की राह पर / तरक्की करना।

content.usage: With her talent and dedication, she is definitely going places.

extras.mnemonic: Moving forward to new and better 'places' implies progress.
extras.origin: A person who is traveling to many places is moving forward. Metaphorically, 'going places' means moving up in the world towards success and fame.

meanings.english: Under consideration; rumor or feeling that is spreading.
meanings.hindi: हवा में होना (चर्चा में या विचाराधीन)।

content.usage: Rumors of a merger are in the air.

extras.mnemonic: Something floating in the air is everywhere but not yet landed (settled).
extras.origin: Like pollen, smoke, or a virus, things in the air spread to everyone but haven't settled yet. A rumor 'in the air' is felt by everyone but not confirmed.

meanings.english: To be in loss or debt.
meanings.hindi: घाटे में होना / कर्ज में होना।

content.usage: The company has been in the red for three consecutive years.

extras.mnemonic: Accountants traditionally used red ink to record losses and black for profits.
extras.origin: In traditional bookkeeping, profits were written in black ink and losses in red ink. Being 'in the red' literally meant your account page was full of red ink—debt.

meanings.english: Unable to leave somewhere because of a problem (no transport/money).
meanings.hindi: फंस जाना / असहाय छोड़ दिया जाना।

content.usage: We were left stranded at the airport when the last flight was cancelled.

extras.mnemonic: A ship that runs aground is 'stranded' on the beach (strand).
extras.origin: A 'strand' is an old word for a beach. A ship driven onto the strand is 'stranded'—stuck on land and unable to move. It means being stuck without resources.

meanings.english: To depart, leave, or go away.

content.usage: I must be off now; I have a train to catch.

extras.mnemonic: To take oneself 'off' the current spot.
extras.origin: Simply means to move 'off' or away from your current position. 'I must be off' is a polite way of saying 'I must move away now'.

meanings.english: To speak and act honestly.

content.usage: You can trust him; his business dealings are always on the square.

extras.mnemonic: A square has straight, even sides; implies fairness and lack of crookedness.
extras.origin: In stonemasonry and Freemasonry, a 'square' is a tool to ensure angles are perfect and true. Being 'on the square' means being honest, fair, and perfectly aligned with the truth.

meanings.english: Broadcast over radio or TV.

content.usage: The interview will be on the air tonight at 8 PM.

extras.mnemonic: Radio waves travel through the air.
extras.origin: Radio signals travel as waves through the air. When a program is broadcasting, it is literally 'on the air' waves.

meanings.english: A device not working properly.

content.usage: The elevator is out of order, so we have to use the stairs.

extras.mnemonic: Order implies proper arrangement/function; out of it means broken.
extras.origin: Parliamentary procedures follow strict 'orders' (rules). If you break them, you are 'out of order'. For machines, it means the internal order of parts is broken.

content.phrase: Be a dab hand at something

meanings.english: Skilled; expert at something.

content.usage: She is a dab hand at painting landscapes.

extras.mnemonic: Dabbing paint precisely requires skill.
extras.origin: A 'dab' is a light, skillful touch (like dabbing paint). A 'dab hand' is someone with that expert, gentle touch needed for detailed work.

meanings.english: Controlled by someone.
meanings.hindi: किसी के इशारों पर नाचना / मुट्ठी में होना।

content.usage: He is completely under his wife's thumb.

extras.mnemonic: Being pinned down under a thumb suggests being small and powerless.
extras.origin: If you pin a bug down with your thumb, it cannot move. Being 'under someone's thumb' means they are holding you down and controlling your every move.

meanings.english: Be very different.

content.usage: Their political views are worlds apart.

extras.mnemonic: If you are on different planets (worlds), you are very far and different.
extras.origin: Imagine two people living on different planets. Their environments and lives are totally different. Being 'worlds apart' means having zero common ground.

meanings.english: To move quickly towards someone in a threatening way; to apply pressure.
meanings.hindi: दबाव डालना / किसी की ओर तेजी से बढ़ना।

content.usage: The storm was bearing down on the island.

extras.mnemonic: A bear pressing down its weight is threatening.
extras.origin: Nautical term. To 'bear down' meant to sail downwind towards an enemy ship, using the wind's force to approach aggressively and attack.

meanings.english: Produce positive results.

content.usage: Our hard work finally began to bear fruit.

extras.mnemonic: A tree that bears fruit is successful; similarly, a plan that works.
extras.origin: A tree is planted with the hope it will produce fruit. When it finally 'bears fruit', the work is rewarded. It means a plan finally producing results.

meanings.english: Remember; take into account.

content.usage: Please bear in mind that the deadline is tomorrow.

extras.mnemonic: To carry (bear) a thought in your head (mind).
extras.origin: To 'bear' means to carry. 'Bear in mind' literally means to carry a specific thought or fact inside your mind so you don't lose it.

meanings.english: Suffer the worst part of something.
meanings.hindi: खामियाजा भुगतना / सबसे भारी चोट सहना।

content.usage: Ordinary citizens often bear the brunt of rising prices.

extras.mnemonic: Brunt sounds like 'burn'; taking the main heat/impact.
extras.origin: From the 14th century, 'brunt' meant a sharp blow or attack. The front line of an army 'bore the brunt'—took the main force—of the enemy charge.

meanings.english: To win; to be victorious.

content.usage: He bore the palm in the debate competition.

extras.mnemonic: Palm leaves were symbols of victory in ancient times.
extras.origin: In ancient Rome, victorious gladiators and athletes were awarded palm branches. To 'bear the palm' meant to carry the trophy of victory.

meanings.english: Endure; tolerate.

content.usage: You must bear up with the pain until the doctor arrives.

extras.mnemonic: Holding yourself 'up' while carrying a heavy 'bear' (load).
extras.origin: Imagine carrying a heavy load (bearing it) but keeping your head up. 'Bearing up' implies finding the strength to remain standing despite the weight of trouble.

meanings.english: To put forth one's maximum effort; to think very hard.

content.usage: I beat my brains out trying to solve this puzzle.

extras.mnemonic: Trying so hard mentally that it feels like physical beating.
extras.origin: Hyperbole. Thinking so hard and intensely that it feels like you are physically beating your own brain to force an idea out.

meanings.english: Dropped or stopped at an early stage.
meanings.hindi: शुरुआत में ही नष्ट कर देना / सिर मुडाते ही ओले पड़ना (रोक देना)।

content.usage: The rebellion was nipped in the bud by the army.

extras.mnemonic: If you cut a flower bud before it opens, it never becomes a flower.
extras.origin: Gardening. If you pinch (nip) a bud off a plant before it opens, it will never become a flower or fruit. It means stopping a problem at the very start.

meanings.english: Cannot be described; defies description.

content.usage: The beauty of the Taj Mahal beggars description.

extras.mnemonic: To make the power of description 'poor' (beggar) because words aren't enough.
extras.origin: Shakespeare (Antony and Cleopatra). To 'beggar' means to make poor. Something so beautiful that it makes the words used to describe it seem poor and inadequate.

meanings.english: Do something secretly.
meanings.hindi: गुप्त रूप से / बंद कमरे में।

content.usage: The deal was negotiated behind closed doors.

extras.mnemonic: If the doors are closed, outsiders can't see what is happening.
extras.origin: Literal. Business conducted in a room with the doors shut is hidden from the public. It implies secrecy and exclusion.

meanings.english: Unknown to everyone; happening out of public view.

content.usage: A lot of hard work goes on behind the scenes of a play.

extras.mnemonic: Backstage in a theater (behind the scenery) where the audience can't see.
extras.origin: Theater. The 'scenes' are the painted backdrops. The actors and crew work 'behind the scenes' where the audience can't see the mechanics of the show.

meanings.english: Make every possible effort.
meanings.hindi: एड़ी-चोटी का जोर लगाना / हर संभव प्रयास करना।

content.usage: He bent over backwards to help us get the loan.

extras.mnemonic: Gymnasts bend backwards; it's difficult and requires effort. Doing it for someone shows dedication.
extras.origin: Gymnastics. Bending backwards is physically difficult and unnatural. Doing it for someone else implies making an extreme, uncomfortable effort to please them.

meanings.english: Irrelevant.

content.usage: Your argument is interesting but beside the mark.

extras.mnemonic: If an arrow lands 'beside' the target (mark), it missed the point.
extras.origin: Archery. The 'mark' is the target. If your arrow lands 'beside the mark', you missed it. It means your comment is irrelevant or wrong.

meanings.english: A situation where someone enjoys the advantages of two different opportunities.
meanings.hindi: दोनों हाथों में लड्डू / दोहरी सुविधा।

content.usage: Working part-time allows her to earn money and spend time with kids—the best of both worlds.

extras.mnemonic: Enjoying Earth and Heaven simultaneously.
extras.origin: Religious/Literary. Originally referred to enjoying the best of this world (Earth) and the next (Heaven). Now means enjoying the pros of two different situations.

meanings.english: Most useful innovation in a long time.
meanings.hindi: बहुत ही बेहतरीन आविष्कार या वस्तु।

content.usage: He thinks this new app is the best thing since sliced bread.

extras.mnemonic: Sliced bread (invented 1928) was a huge convenience; anything better is amazing.
extras.origin: Sliced bread (invented 1928) saved people the daily hassle of cutting bread. It was marketed as the greatest step forward in baking. Now used for any great innovation.

meanings.english: Unreasonable and unacceptable.

content.usage: His rude behavior at the funeral was beyond the pale.

extras.mnemonic: Pale means a boundary/fence (paling). Going beyond it means going outside civilized area.
extras.origin: Historical. The 'Pale' was the safe territory around Dublin under English rule. Beyond the Pale was the wild, uncivilized land. Going there meant leaving civilization.

meanings.english: A lot of money.

content.usage: Professional athletes make big bucks.

extras.mnemonic: Buck is slang for dollar.
extras.origin: 'Buck' is slang for a dollar, possibly from buckskins (deer skins) used as currency by frontiersmen. 'Big bucks' just means a huge pile of money.

meanings.english: Speak angrily without good reason.

content.usage: I just asked the time, and she bit my head off!

extras.mnemonic: Imagine a monster so angry it bites your head off just for saying hello.
extras.origin: Hyperbole. Imagine a monster or dragon that bites off heads. A person who reacts with sudden, savage anger is compared to such a beast.

meanings.english: To force yourself to do something unpleasant.
meanings.hindi: कड़वा घूँट पीना / मजबूरी में दुःख झेलना।

content.usage: I hate dentists, but I have to bite the bullet and go.

extras.mnemonic: Soldiers bit on a bullet during surgery without anesthesia.
extras.origin: Before anesthesia, soldiers undergoing surgery were given a bullet to bite down on to cope with the agony. It means enduring pain or a difficult task bravely.

meanings.english: To stop yourself from saying anything.
meanings.hindi: जुबान पर लगाम लगाना / चुप रहना।

content.usage: I wanted to argue, but I bit my tongue to avoid a scene.

extras.mnemonic: If you bite your tongue physically, you can't speak.
extras.origin: If you bite your tongue, it hurts and you physically cannot speak. Metaphorically, it means forcing yourself to stay silent despite wanting to talk.

meanings.english: Misfortune; adversity.

content.usage: The black ox has trodden on his foot (he has known sorrow).

extras.mnemonic: Black often symbolizes bad luck/death; Ox symbolizes heavy burden.
extras.origin: An old proverb: 'The black ox has trod on his foot'. The black ox symbolized old age, death, or misfortune. It means bad luck has arrived.

meanings.english: Person with bad reputation in a family or group.

content.usage: He is the black sheep of the family because he dropped out of school.

extras.mnemonic: Black sheep wool couldn't be dyed and was worth less than white wool.
extras.origin: Black wool cannot be dyed, so black sheep were less valuable to farmers. Also, they stood out in a white flock. It means the odd or disreputable member.

meanings.english: A situation in which no further progress can be made.
meanings.hindi: बंद गली / ऐसी स्थिति जहाँ से आगे बढ़ने का रास्ता न हो।

content.usage: The investigation turned out to be a blind alley.

extras.mnemonic: An alley that is closed at one end (cul-de-sac).
extras.origin: An alley that is closed at one end (a cul-de-sac). You walk in but can't go through; you have to turn back. It represents a path with no future.

meanings.english: To react very angrily.
meanings.hindi: आग बबूला होना / बहुत गुस्सा होना।

content.usage: Dad will blow a fuse when he sees the dent in the car.

extras.mnemonic: When a fuse blows, the circuit breaks violently; similar to losing temper.
extras.origin: Electrical. If a fuse blows, the circuit breaks instantly and often with a spark. It describes a sudden, explosive loss of temper.

meanings.english: Be very angry.

content.usage: He blew his top when he found out they lost the files.

extras.mnemonic: Like a volcano blowing its top (erupting).
extras.origin: Like a volcano erupting or a steam engine blowing its safety valve. The pressure inside (anger) becomes too high and blows the top off.

meanings.english: Pass off; to fade away without serious consequences.

content.usage: Don't worry about the scandal; it will soon blow over.

extras.mnemonic: Like a storm cloud blowing over your head and moving away.
extras.origin: Weather. A storm cloud might look threatening, but if the wind blows it over your head, it passes without raining on you. The trouble passes without harm.

meanings.english: Sums up to; the main point.

content.usage: The issue boils down to a lack of money.

extras.mnemonic: When you boil a liquid, the water evaporates and leaves the concentrated substance.
extras.origin: Cooking. If you boil a sauce, the water evaporates and leaves only the essential, concentrated flavor. 'Boiling down' an issue gets to the core point.

meanings.english: Cause of quarrel; a grievance to discuss.

content.usage: I have a bone to pick with you about the broken vase.

extras.mnemonic: A dog picking (chewing) a bone is busy and maybe aggressive; discussing a problem is chewing on it.
extras.origin: A dog chewing (picking) a bone is occupied and determined. If you have a bone to pick with someone, you have a specific issue you want to chew over with them.

meanings.english: Force entry illegally.

content.usage: Thieves tried to break in while we were on vacation.

extras.mnemonic: Breaking a lock to get in.
extras.origin: Literal. Thieves physically break a door or window to get in. It means entering by force.

meanings.english: To do or discover something new.
meanings.hindi: नई शुरुआत करना / नई खोज करना।

content.usage: The scientists broke new ground in cancer research.

extras.mnemonic: Construction: digging ground to build something new.
extras.origin: Construction. Before building, you must break the solid ground to lay foundations. Breaking new ground implies starting a pioneering project.

meanings.english: To end a relationship or stop abruptly.

content.usage: They decided to break off their engagement.

extras.mnemonic: Breaking a stick off makes it separate; separating from a person.
extras.origin: Breaking a stick or branch snaps it into two pieces. 'Breaking off' a relationship or talk implies a sudden, sharp separation.

meanings.english: To use bad grammar.

content.usage: By saying 'ain't', he broke Priscian's head.

extras.mnemonic: Priscian was a famous Latin grammarian; speaking badly hurts him (breaks his head).
extras.origin: Priscian was a famous Latin grammarian (500 AD). His head symbolized grammar rules. Speaking badly was metaphorically hitting or breaking his head.

meanings.english: A support that failed; an unreliable person.

content.usage: I thought he would help, but he proved to be a broken reed.

extras.mnemonic: A reed is a thin plant stem; if broken, it cannot support any weight.
extras.origin: Biblical (Isaiah 36:6). Egypt was called a 'broken reed'—a support that looks like a staff but snaps when you lean on it, piercing your hand.

meanings.english: To argue or compete against.

content.usage: He was ready to break a lance with the professor over the theory.

extras.mnemonic: In jousting, knights broke lances against opponents.
extras.origin: Medieval Jousting. Knights charged and broke their wooden lances against the opponent's shield. Breaking a lance meant engaging in combat or argument.

meanings.english: Watching all his actions closely; monitoring oppressively.
meanings.hindi: सिर पर सवार रहना / बारीकी से निगरानी करना।

content.usage: I can't work with the boss breathing down my neck all day.

extras.mnemonic: Standing so close behind someone that they can feel your breath.
extras.origin: If someone stands right behind you, you can feel their breath on your neck. It describes uncomfortable, close surveillance.

meanings.english: A useless task; fighting against nothing.
meanings.hindi: व्यर्थ प्रयास करना / हवा में लाठी चलाना।

content.usage: Trying to convince him is just beating the air.

extras.mnemonic: If you punch the air, you hit nothing and achieve nothing.
extras.origin: Boxing. If a boxer misses the opponent and punches the air, he exerts energy but hits nothing. It means fighting a pointless battle.

meanings.english: To be successful; to earn a living.

content.usage: She works hard to bring home the bacon for her family.

extras.mnemonic: Bacon was a valuable meat; bringing it home meant you provided well.
extras.origin: Bacon was a staple meat for commoners. Bringing it home meant you had earned enough to feed your family. Also tied to catching a greased pig at fairs.

meanings.english: Make the audience applaud enthusiastically.
meanings.hindi: वाह-वाही लूटना / दर्शकों को मंत्रमुग्ध करना।

content.usage: Her performance brought the house down.

extras.mnemonic: The noise of applause is so loud it could collapse the building (house).
extras.origin: Theater. If the audience claps and stamps so hard, it feels like the vibrations could make the building (house) collapse. It means massive success.

meanings.english: A deep thoughtfulness; reverie.

content.usage: He was in a brown study and didn't hear me enter.

extras.mnemonic: Brown suggests gloom or seriousness; studying implies deep thought.
extras.origin: From French *brun* meaning gloomy. A 'brown study' is a state of deep, perhaps melancholy, absorption in thought.

meanings.english: Irritates me.

content.usage: It really bugs me when people chew with their mouths open.

extras.mnemonic: Bugs (insects) are annoying.
extras.origin: Insects (bugs) buzz and bite, causing irritation. If something 'bugs' you, it pesters and annoys you like a fly.

meanings.english: Centre of target.

content.usage: His prediction hit the bull's eye.

extras.mnemonic: The center of a target often looks like the eye of a bull.
extras.origin: Archery. The center of a target was often black, looking like the eye of a bull. Hitting it meant a perfect shot.

meanings.english: Interrupt.
meanings.hindi: बीच में टांग अड़ाना / हस्तक्षेप करना।

content.usage: Please don't butt in while we are talking.

extras.mnemonic: A goat butts with its horns; pushing into a conversation forcefully.
extras.origin: Goats and rams fight by butting heads. 'Butting in' means thrusting yourself into a conversation or line forcefully like a ram.

meanings.english: Clumsy person (who drops things).
meanings.hindi: बेढंगा व्यक्ति / जिसके हाथ से चीजें छूटती हों।

content.usage: Throw the ball to him gently; he's a butter fingers.

extras.mnemonic: If your fingers are covered in butter, things slip out easily.
extras.origin: If your fingers were covered in slippery butter, you couldn't hold anything—cups and balls would slip. It describes a clumsy person.

meanings.english: Stop talking.

content.usage: She told him to button his lip and listen.

extras.mnemonic: Imagine buttons sealing your lips shut like a shirt.
extras.origin: Imagine your lips are the fabric of a coat. Buttoning them together physically seals your mouth so you cannot speak.

meanings.english: By a very small margin.
meanings.hindi: बाल-बाल बचना / बहुत कम अंतर से।

content.usage: He won the race by a whisker.

extras.mnemonic: A whisker (hair) is very thin.
extras.origin: A cat's whisker is extremely thin. Winning by a whisker means winning by a distance as thin as a hair—a tiny margin.

meanings.english: Gradually; before long.

content.usage: You will get used to the new city by and by.

extras.mnemonic: Repetition implies passage of time.
extras.origin: Old English repetition. As time passes 'by' (near) and then another 'by' comes, it implies the gradual passage of time.

meanings.english: In general; considering everything.

content.usage: By and large, the plan was successful.

extras.mnemonic: Sailing term: sailing 'by' (close to wind) and 'large' (with wind); covers all conditions.
extras.origin: Nautical. Sailing 'by' meant close to the wind; sailing 'large' meant with the wind. 'By and large' covered all sailing conditions, meaning 'in general'.

meanings.english: Given or allowed by; thanks to.

content.usage: The event was organized by courtesy of the local council.

extras.mnemonic: Courtesy = politeness/favor.
extras.origin: 'Courtesy' means politeness or favor. If something is provided 'by courtesy of' someone, it is a polite gift from them.

meanings.english: In any way possible, whether honest or dishonest.
meanings.hindi: येन केन प्रकारेण / अच्छे या बुरे किसी भी तरीके से।

content.usage: He is determined to win the election by fair means or foul.

extras.mnemonic: Fair = good rules, Foul = bad rules; using both.
extras.origin: To win by following the rules (fair) or by breaking them (foul). It means doing whatever it takes, ignoring morality.

meanings.english: Very quickly; rapidly.
meanings.hindi: दिन दूनी रात चौगुनी / तेजी से।

content.usage: India's economy is growing by leaps and bounds.

extras.mnemonic: Leaping means jumping far; bounding means moving fast.
extras.origin: A leap is a long jump; a bound is a springy jump. Moving by 'leaps and bounds' covers huge distance very quickly.

meanings.english: In the same way; for the same reason.

content.usage: You must respect your parents, and by the same token, they should respect your choices.

extras.mnemonic: A token is a sign/proof; same token means same proof/logic applies.
extras.origin: A token was a coin or proof. 'By the same token' implies that the same evidence or logic applies to this new situation.

meanings.english: Criticize; scold.

content.usage: The teacher called him down for being late.

extras.mnemonic: Calling down judgment from above.
extras.origin: Calling upon divine power to come down and punish. Now implies a superior scolding a subordinate.

meanings.english: Challenge; cast doubt on.

content.usage: His honesty was called in question after the theft.

extras.mnemonic: To call something 'into' the area of questioning.
extras.origin: To summon a witness or idea into the court for questioning. It means to challenge the truth of something.

meanings.english: Decide or agree to stop doing something (usually work).
meanings.hindi: काम रोकना / आज का काम खत्म करना।

content.usage: We've been working for 10 hours; let's call it a day.

extras.mnemonic: Declaring that the 'day' (work day) is finished.
extras.origin: Originally 'call it half a day' when leaving early. Now, 'calling it a day' declares the work session officially over.

meanings.english: Pay a visit; or ask someone to speak.

content.usage: We plan to call on our grandmother this Sunday.

extras.mnemonic: To 'call' at someone's door.
extras.origin: Social etiquette. To 'call' meant to stop at someone's house for a visit. 'Calling on' someone is paying them a visit.

meanings.english: To be in control; to make the decisions.

content.usage: In this company, the CEO calls the shots.

extras.mnemonic: In target practice, calling where the shot will hit shows control.
extras.origin: Marksmanship. A skilled shooter tells the audience exactly where he will hit the target ('calling the shot'). It implies control and authority.

meanings.english: To be unable to do a job; not good enough.
meanings.hindi: उम्मीद पर खरा न उतरना / काम करने में असमर्थ।

content.usage: He was fired because he couldn't cut the mustard.

extras.mnemonic: Mustard was slang for 'the best' or 'genuine' thing; if you can't cut (achieve) it, you fail.
extras.origin: Cowboy slang. 'Mustard' meant the best or genuine thing. If you couldn't 'cut' (achieve) the mustard standard, you weren't good enough.

meanings.english: In a respectful or humble manner (often asking for money/favor).

content.usage: He had to go cap in hand to his father for a loan.

extras.mnemonic: Taking off your cap and holding it is a sign of respect and begging.
extras.origin: A gesture of humility. A poor man would take off his cap and hold it in his hand while asking a rich man for money. It implies begging.

meanings.english: To take the blame or responsibility.
meanings.hindi: जिम्मेदारी लेना / इल्जाम अपने सिर लेना।

content.usage: The manager resigned, leaving his deputy to carry the can.

extras.mnemonic: Carrying a can of dangerous material (explosives) for someone else.
extras.origin: Military slang. One person was chosen to carry the heavy bucket (can) of beer or explosives for the squad. If anything spilled, they got the blame.

meanings.english: Be important or influential.

content.usage: Her opinion carries a lot of weight in the committee.

extras.mnemonic: Heavy things have impact; weighty opinions matter.
extras.origin: Physical weight has impact—a heavy object leaves a mark. An opinion that 'carries weight' has significance and influence.

meanings.english: Develop a specific position for oneself.
meanings.hindi: अपनी जगह बनाना / विशिष्ट स्थान प्राप्त करना।

content.usage: She carved out a niche for herself in the fashion industry.

extras.mnemonic: Carving a spot in a wall (niche) to place a statue.
extras.origin: Architecture. A niche is a recess carved into a wall to hold a statue. Carving out a niche means creating a special place that fits you perfectly.

meanings.english: Extremely short of money.

content.usage: The cash-strapped airline cancelled many flights.

extras.mnemonic: Strapped (bound) tightly so cash can't move/exist.
extras.origin: Imagine being strapped down so you can't move. A 'cash-strapped' person is immobilized because they lack the money to move or act.

meanings.english: Damage reputation; defame.

content.usage: His comments cast a slur upon the integrity of the team.

extras.mnemonic: Slur means a smear or stain; casting it throws dirt on someone.
extras.origin: 'Slur' meant thin mud. Casting a slur is metaphorically throwing mud on someone's reputation to stain it.

meanings.english: A dilemma or difficult circumstance from which there is no escape because of mutually conflicting or dependent conditions.
meanings.hindi: विषम स्थिति / जहाँ से निकलना असंभव हो।

content.usage: I can't get a job without experience, but I can't get experience without a job. It's a Catch-22.

extras.mnemonic: From the book where Rule 22 trapped pilots in a loop.
extras.origin: From Joseph Heller's novel 'Catch-22'. Pilots could stop flying if crazy, but asking to stop proved they were sane (and had to fly). A logical trap.

meanings.english: To deal with a person who is stronger or more difficult than expected.
meanings.hindi: शेर को सवा शेर मिलना / अपने से मजबूत से पाला पड़ना।

content.usage: The burglar thought the old man was weak, but he caught a Tartar.

extras.mnemonic: Tartars were fierce warriors; catching one meant you were actually in trouble.
extras.origin: Military story. A soldier shouted he caught a Tartar (fierce warrior). The Tartar wouldn't let him go. It means capturing someone who is actually stronger than you.

meanings.english: Seize the opportunity.

content.usage: You must catch time by the forelock and apply for the job now.

extras.mnemonic: Time is depicted as an old man bald at the back but with hair (forelock) in front; you must grab him as he approaches, or you miss him.
extras.origin: Mythology. Opportunity (Kairos) was depicted as bald in the back but with a lock of hair (forelock) in front. You must grab him as he approaches, or you miss him.

meanings.english: To be highly impressive or excellent.

content.usage: He thinks he is the cat's whiskers in that new suit.

extras.mnemonic: Cats are elegant; 'whiskers' was 1920s slang for excellent things.
extras.origin: 1920s slang. Nonsense phrases involving animals (like 'bee's knees') were trendy. Cats are elegant, so 'cat's whiskers' meant something stylish and excellent.

meanings.english: Turned pale (due to fear) or red (due to embarrassment).
meanings.hindi: चेहरे का रंग उड़ जाना / पीला पड़ जाना।

content.usage: He changed colour when the police asked for his ID.

extras.mnemonic: Blood leaving the face changes its color.
extras.origin: Blood flow. Shock drains blood (pale/white), embarrassment rushes blood (red). Your face literally changes color based on emotion.

meanings.english: Provide minute detail; exact reference.

content.usage: He can give you chapter and verse on the company's history.

extras.mnemonic: Citing the exact chapter and verse of the Bible implies total accuracy.
extras.origin: Biblical. To prove a point, one would cite the exact Chapter and Verse of the scripture. It implies giving precise, verifiable evidence.

meanings.english: Very close together; side by side.

content.usage: The rich and poor lived cheek by jowl in the old city.

extras.mnemonic: Cheek touching Jowl (jaw/cheek area); faces pressing together.
extras.origin: Jowl is the cheek/jaw area. 'Cheek by jowl' means faces touching—people standing so close they are practically hugging or crowding each other.

meanings.english: Discuss or think about something at length.

content.usage: Let's meet tomorrow to chew over the proposal.

extras.mnemonic: Like a cow chewing cud repeatedly to digest it; digesting ideas.
extras.origin: Cows chew cud (regurgitated food) slowly to digest it. 'Chewing over' a thought means processing it slowly and thoroughly in your mind.

meanings.english: Very little money.
meanings.hindi: बहुत कम रकम / नाममात्र की राशि।

content.usage: He refused the job because the salary was chicken feed.

extras.mnemonic: Food for chickens is cheap grain; small value.
extras.origin: Chickens are small, and their feed (grain) is cheap. Calling money 'chicken feed' insults it as being too small an amount to matter.

meanings.english: To decide not to do something because of fear.

content.usage: He wanted to bungee jump but chickened out at the last minute.

extras.mnemonic: Chickens are timid birds.
extras.origin: Chickens run away from noise. To 'chicken out' implies acting like a scared bird and fleeing a challenge.

content.phrase: Children should be seen and not heard

meanings.english: Children should be well-behaved and silent in the presence of adults.
meanings.hindi: बच्चों को बड़ों के बीच चुप रहना चाहिए।

content.usage: In the Victorian era, the rule was that children should be seen and not heard.

extras.mnemonic: Self-explanatory proverb.
extras.origin: Victorian etiquette. Children were expected to be present and well-behaved (seen) but not to speak or disturb adults (not heard).

meanings.english: A weakness or vulnerable point.

content.usage: His arrogance is the only chink in his armour.

extras.mnemonic: A chink is a gap in a knight's metal armour where an arrow can enter.
extras.origin: Knights wore metal armor. A 'chink' was a small gap between plates. An arrow hitting there could kill. It represents a fatal weakness.

meanings.english: Involving mystery, intrigue, or espionage.
meanings.hindi: रहस्य और षड्यंत्र से भरा / जासूसी।

content.usage: It was a cloak and dagger operation by the secret service.

extras.mnemonic: Spies wear cloaks to hide and carry daggers to kill.
extras.origin: Drama. Spies and assassins in plays wore cloaks to hide their identity and carried daggers. It refers to mysterious, spy-like behavior.

meanings.english: To stop working on something; to consider a matter settled.
meanings.hindi: अध्याय समाप्त करना / काम बंद करना।

content.usage: The police closed the book on the case after finding no evidence.

extras.mnemonic: Closing a book means you are done reading/writing it.
extras.origin: Accounting/Police. Closing the book on a case or ledger means the work is finished and no more entries will be made. The matter is settled.

meanings.english: The evil intention; sign of the devil.

content.usage: He seemed kind, but eventually showed the cloven hoof.

extras.mnemonic: The Devil is depicted with cloven (split) hooves like a goat.
extras.origin: Folklore. The Devil is often depicted with the split (cloven) hooves of a goat. Seeing the cloven hoof reveals the evil nature beneath a disguise.

meanings.english: Slight or no satisfaction; very little consolation.
meanings.hindi: ना के बराबर तसल्ली / झूठी तसल्ली।

content.usage: The apology was cold comfort for the damage caused.

extras.mnemonic: Comfort usually implies warmth; cold comfort is barely comfort at all.
extras.origin: Shakespeare. Cold comfort is an oxymoron—it provides no warmth. It means the consolation offered is so small it doesn't make you feel better.

meanings.english: Carefully look through or search thoroughly.

content.usage: Police combed through the evidence to find a clue.

extras.mnemonic: A comb goes through every strand of hair; similarly, searching every detail.
extras.origin: Grooming. A fine-toothed comb goes through every strand of hair to remove lice. Combing through data means searching every tiny detail.

meanings.english: No matter what happens; despite any difficulties.
meanings.hindi: चाहे जो हो जाए / किसी भी परिस्थिति में।

content.usage: I will be at your wedding come hell or high water.

extras.mnemonic: Facing fire (hell) or flood (high water), I will still come.
extras.origin: American frontier. 'Hell' (fire) and 'High Water' (floods) were the worst obstacles. Coming despite them means nothing will stop you.

meanings.english: Turn out to be useful.

content.usage: Keep that rope; it might come in handy later.

extras.mnemonic: Handy = near the hand/ready to use.
