extras.origin: Tools that are near your hand are 'handy' and ready to use. If something 'comes in handy', it proves useful at the right moment.

meanings.english: Reach maturity or adulthood (legally).

content.usage: He will inherit the money when he comes of age.

extras.mnemonic: Reaching the 'age' of responsibility.
extras.origin: Legal. Historically, 21 was the age of maturity. Coming of age meant reaching the legal year when you could inherit property and vote.

meanings.english: Be separated; succeed; happen.
meanings.hindi: अलग होना / सफल होना / घटित होना।

content.usage: The handle came off the door. / The plan didn't come off.

extras.mnemonic: Phrasal verb with multiple meanings depending on context.
extras.origin: Phrasal verb. Can mean a part detaching (button came off) or a plan succeeding (it came off well).

meanings.english: Get into a physical fight.

content.usage: The argument heated up, and they nearly came to blows.

extras.mnemonic: To reach the stage of exchanging blows (punches).
extras.origin: Fighting. To move from words to physical punches (blows). It implies the argument has escalated to violence.

meanings.english: Have an accident; fail completely.

content.usage: The project came to grief due to poor planning.

extras.mnemonic: To arrive at a state of sadness (grief) due to failure.
extras.origin: Literary. 'Grief' implies sorrow or disaster. A ship that hits rocks comes to grief. It means ending in tragedy or failure.

meanings.english: Gradually accept a sad or difficult situation.

content.usage: She eventually came to terms with her illness.

extras.mnemonic: To agree to the 'terms' of reality, even if harsh.
extras.origin: Negotiation. To come to terms is to agree on a contract. Metaphorically, it means making a mental deal to accept a hard reality.

meanings.english: To falsify financial records dishonestly.
meanings.hindi: हिसाब-किताब में गड़बड़ी करना / बही-खाते में हेराफेरी करना।

content.usage: The accountant was jailed for cooking the books to hide the company's losses.

extras.mnemonic: Cooking ingredients changes them; cooking books changes the numbers.
extras.origin: Cooking ingredients changes their form. 'Cooking' the books implies changing the numbers so they look different (and better) than they really are—fraud.

meanings.english: Ready to work; not anxious but relaxed.
meanings.hindi: काम करने के लिए तैयार / शांत।

content.usage: She is quite cool about working on weekends.

extras.mnemonic: Being 'cool' means relaxed and willing.
extras.origin: Slang. Being 'cool' means not being hot-headed or anxious. It implies a relaxed, accepting attitude towards a task.

meanings.english: To be kept waiting.

content.usage: I was left to cool my heels in the reception for two hours.

extras.mnemonic: Walking makes heels hot; standing still waiting makes them cool down.
extras.origin: Travel. Horses running fast have hot hooves. If you stop and wait, their heels cool down. It implies being forced to wait long enough for your heels to cool.

meanings.english: Handle; deal with effectively.

content.usage: It is difficult to cope with the stress of a new job.

extras.mnemonic: Cope ~ Capable; being capable of handling things.
extras.origin: From Old French *couper* (to strike). Originally meant to come to blows with; now means to handle or manage a struggle successfully.

meanings.english: Isolated or enclosed by a barrier (usually by police).

content.usage: The police cordoned off the crime scene.

extras.mnemonic: A cordon is a ribbon/rope; tying it off prevents entry.
extras.origin: Military. A 'cordon' is a line of guards or a rope/ribbon blocking access. To cordon off means to isolate an area with a barrier.

meanings.english: Be grateful for what one has.
meanings.hindi: अपनी खुशकिस्मती के लिए आभारी होना।

content.usage: Instead of complaining, you should count your blessings.

extras.mnemonic: Making a list (counting) of good things in life.
extras.origin: From the hymn 'Count Your Blessings' (1897). It encourages listing good things one by one to realize how lucky you are.

meanings.english: To laugh out loud; or to suffer a mental breakdown.

content.usage: The joke was so funny that the whole class cracked up.

extras.mnemonic: A hard shell cracks open; likewise, composure cracks into laughter.
extras.origin: Slang. A face 'cracks' into a smile. If you crack up, you lose composure completely, either laughing wildly or having a breakdown.

meanings.english: To fail completely and spectacularly.

content.usage: His startup crashed and burned within six months.

extras.mnemonic: Like a plane crashing and catching fire; total destruction.
extras.origin: Aviation. If a plane crashes and burns, it is a total, spectacular loss. It describes a failure that is sudden and complete.

meanings.english: Eliminate or delete by drawing a line through.

content.usage: Cross out the wrong answer on the sheet.

extras.mnemonic: Making a cross (X) over something to cancel it.
extras.origin: Writing. Drawing a cross (X) or a line through text deletes it. It means removing or cancelling an item.

content.phrase: Cross the bridge when one comes to it

meanings.english: Solve a problem only when it happens, not before.
meanings.hindi: मुसीबत आने पर ही उसका सामना करना।

content.usage: Don't worry about money yet; we'll cross that bridge when we come to it.

extras.mnemonic: No need to walk over a bridge (solve problem) until you are actually at the river.
extras.origin: Proverb. Don't worry about crossing a river until you actually reach the bridge. It advises saving worry for when the problem actually arises.

meanings.english: Disagreed or argued; fought.

content.usage: The two politicians crossed swords over the new tax law.

extras.mnemonic: Knights crossing swords to begin a duel.
extras.origin: Fencing. A duel begins when the swords touch (cross). 'Crossing swords' metaphorically means engaging in an argument or conflict.

meanings.english: A critical moment near the end of a process when decisive action is needed.

content.usage: It's crunch time for the students as exams begin next week.

extras.mnemonic: The pressure is so high you can feel the 'crunch'.
extras.origin: Sports/Business. The sound of a 'crunch' implies heavy pressure. Crunch time is the critical, high-pressure period right before a deadline.

meanings.english: To depreciate; disparage; to belittle.
meanings.hindi: निंदा करना / कीमत या महत्व घटाना।

content.usage: He is always trying to cry down my achievements.

extras.mnemonic: Crying (shouting) someone 'down' to make them feel small.
extras.origin: Archaic. To 'cry' (shout) someone down is to silence them by being louder. It means to belittle or criticize loudly.

meanings.english: An unrealistic demand; an unheeded warning; expressing an unpopular opinion.
meanings.hindi: अरण्य रोदन / भैंस के आगे बीन बजाना (व्यर्थ पुकार)।

content.usage: His warning about the economy was just a cry in the wilderness.

extras.mnemonic: If you scream in a desert (wilderness), nobody hears you.
extras.origin: Biblical (Matthew 3:3). John the Baptist preached in the wilderness where few heard. It refers to a warning or truth that goes ignored by the majority.

meanings.english: To ingratiate oneself with someone through obsequious behavior.

content.usage: He tried to curry favour with the boss by buying him lunch.

extras.mnemonic: Originally 'Curry Favel' (Favel was a horse in a French story representing cunning/deceit); rubbing the horse meant flattering.
extras.origin: Medieval satire. 'Fauvel' was a horse symbolizing deceit. Rubbing (currying) him meant flattering deceit. 'Fauvel' sounded like 'favour', so it became 'curry favour'.

meanings.english: Created a wrong impression; to appear foolish or poor.
meanings.hindi: बुरा प्रभाव डालना / हंसी का पात्र बनना।

content.usage: He cut a sorry figure in his ill-fitting suit.

extras.mnemonic: Figure = appearance; Sorry = poor/bad.
extras.origin: Figure implies appearance. Cutting a 'sorry' (poor) figure means you look bad or present yourself poorly in a situation.

meanings.english: Ready-made; decided beforehand; completely settled.
meanings.hindi: पहले से तय / स्पष्ट और निश्चित।

content.usage: The decision is cut and dried; there is no room for debate.

extras.mnemonic: Herbs sold in shops are cut and dried, ready to use immediately.
extras.origin: Timber. Wood that is cut and dried is ready for use immediately. It implies a decision that is already fixed and ready, with no room for change.

meanings.english: Do something perfunctorily to save time or money.
meanings.hindi: कामचोरी करना / खर्चा या समय बचाने के लिए गुणवत्ता से समझौता करना।

content.usage: The building collapsed because the contractors cut corners.

extras.mnemonic: Instead of walking the full square path, cutting across the corner saves time but skips part of the route.
extras.origin: Hunting/Driving. If you cut across a corner instead of following the road, you save time but might crash. It means doing a job cheaply and riskily.

content.phrase: Cut him off without a shilling

meanings.english: Disinherited him; gave him no money in the will.

content.usage: After the argument, his father cut him off without a shilling.

extras.mnemonic: Not leaving even a single coin (shilling) to the heir.
extras.origin: Inheritance law. To disinherit a son, a father might leave him nothing—not even a shilling coin. It means total disinheritance.

meanings.english: Interrupt someone while they are speaking; move in front of.

content.usage: She cut in to ask a question during the speech.

extras.mnemonic: Cutting into a line or conversation.
extras.origin: Dancing/Driving. Cutting in means steering your car or body in front of someone else suddenly. It implies interruption.

meanings.english: Have no influence or effect on someone.

content.usage: His excuses cut no ice with the teacher.

extras.mnemonic: A dull blade cannot cut ice; similarly, a weak argument makes no impact.
extras.origin: Ice skating. A dull skate blade slides but cuts no ice (makes no mark). A weak argument similarly makes no impression.

meanings.english: Interrupt someone.

content.usage: I was explaining the problem when he cut me short.

extras.mnemonic: Stopping a speech before it is finished (making it short).
extras.origin: To stop a length of rope or time by cutting it. Cutting someone short means interrupting them before they finish speaking.

meanings.english: Make shorter; end prematurely.
meanings.hindi: छोटा करना / समय से पहले समाप्त करना।

content.usage: The picnic was cut short by the rain.

extras.mnemonic: Cutting something to reduce its length.
extras.origin: To truncate. Like cutting a rope to make it shorter. It means ending an event or trip earlier than planned.

meanings.english: Come to the point; stop talking about unimportant things.

content.usage: We don't have much time, so let's cut to the chase.

extras.mnemonic: In movies, cut (skip) the boring dialogue and go straight to the car chase scene.
extras.origin: Hollywood. Silent films often had boring plots before the exciting chase scene. Producers would say 'Cut to the chase!' to get to the action.

meanings.english: To solve a difficult problem boldly and decisively.
meanings.hindi: जटिल समस्या का हल निकालना (कठोर निर्णय लेकर)।

content.usage: The government cut the Gordian knot by abolishing the old tax system entirely.

extras.mnemonic: Alexander the Great couldn't untie the complex knot, so he cut it with his sword.
extras.origin: Legend. King Gordius tied a complex knot. An oracle said whoever untied it would rule Asia. Alexander the Great simply sliced it with his sword—a bold solution.

meanings.english: To perform well; to meet expectations.

content.usage: He is too old to play football; he just can't cut the mustard anymore.

extras.mnemonic: Similar to 'pass muster' or mustard being a slang for 'excellent'.
extras.origin: Cowboy slang. 'Mustard' meant the genuine article or best quality. If you couldn't 'cut' (achieve) that level, you weren't good enough.

meanings.english: Hurt intensely (emotionally).
meanings.hindi: दिल को गहरी चोट पहुँचाना / मर्मस्थल पर आघात।

content.usage: Her sarcastic remarks cut him to the quick.

extras.mnemonic: 'Quick' refers to the tender flesh under the fingernail; cutting it hurts a lot.
extras.origin: The 'quick' is the sensitive flesh under fingernails. Cutting down to the quick is extremely painful. It refers to a deeply hurtful comment.

meanings.english: Close contest that ends in a tie.
meanings.hindi: बराबरी की जीत / जिसमें हार-जीत का फैसला न हो सके।

content.usage: The race ended in a dead heat between the two runners.

extras.mnemonic: Heat is a round of a race; dead implies no movement/winner.
extras.origin: Racing. A 'heat' is a race. If two horses finished exactly even, the heat was 'dead'—no winner. It implies a tie.

meanings.english: No chance of success; stalled and unable to move.

content.usage: Without funding, the project is dead in the water.

extras.mnemonic: A ship with no engine/wind sits dead (motionless) in the water.
extras.origin: Nautical. A sailing ship with no wind sits 'dead' (motionless) in the water. It means a project that has stalled completely.

meanings.english: Completely opposed to.

content.usage: My father is dead set against me buying a motorbike.

extras.mnemonic: Set firmly (dead/absolute) in opposition.
extras.origin: A 'dead set' is a hunting term where a dog freezes (sets) pointing at game. Being 'dead set against' implies unmoving, rigid opposition.

meanings.english: Discover damaging information about someone.
meanings.hindi: मुर्दे उखाड़ना / किसी की पोल खोलना।

content.usage: The reporter tried to dig up dirt on the politician.

extras.mnemonic: Digging into someone's past to find 'dirt' (filth/scandal).
extras.origin: Digging into the ground reveals mud and filth. Metaphorically, digging into someone's past to find scandalous 'dirt' to ruin them.

meanings.english: Help someone; perform a kind act.

content.usage: Boy Scouts are encouraged to do a good turn daily.

extras.mnemonic: Turning things in a good direction for someone.
extras.origin: Scouting. A 'turn' is an act or deed. Doing a good turn means performing a helpful act for someone else.

meanings.english: To be highly successful in selling something.

content.usage: The ice cream shop did a roaring trade on the hot day.

extras.mnemonic: Roaring implies loud, busy activity.
extras.origin: A fire that burns strongly makes a roaring sound. A business doing a 'roaring trade' is busy, loud, and successful.

meanings.english: Abolish; kill or get rid of.

content.usage: We should do away with these outdated rules.

extras.mnemonic: To put something 'away' permanently.
extras.origin: To put something 'away' permanently, like in a grave or trash. 'Doing away with' means abolishing or killing.

meanings.english: Ruthless competition where people harm each other to succeed.

content.usage: The banking industry is a dog eat dog world.

extras.mnemonic: Dogs are usually loyal, but in extreme hunger, they might eat each other; implies savage behavior.
extras.origin: Irony. An old Latin proverb said 'dog does not eat dog'. Using it now means the situation is so bad that they ARE eating each other—ruthless competition.

meanings.english: A person who selfishly prevents others from using something they don't need themselves.
meanings.hindi: जो खुद न खाए और न दूसरों को खाने दे।

content.usage: He's a dog in the manger; he won't lend me the book even though he never reads it.

extras.mnemonic: A dog sleeping in a manger (cow's feeder) doesn't eat hay but stops the cow from eating it.
extras.origin: Aesop's Fables. A dog sat in a manger (hay box). He didn't eat hay, but he barked to stop the cows from eating it. It means selfishly denying others.

meanings.english: Ruined; defeated; about to die.
meanings.hindi: बर्बाद हो जाना / काम तमाम होना।

content.usage: If the police catch him, he is done for.

extras.mnemonic: Done = finished.
extras.origin: Cookery. When food is 'done', it is finished cooking. If a person is 'done for', they are finished, ruined, or about to die.

content.phrase: Don't put all your eggs in one basket

meanings.english: Do not put all your resources in one place; diversify risks.
meanings.hindi: सारा दारोमदार एक ही चीज़ पर न रखें।

content.usage: Invest in different stocks; don't put all your eggs in one basket.

extras.mnemonic: If you drop the one basket, all eggs break. Separate them to be safe.
extras.origin: Farming. If you carry all eggs in one basket and drop it, you lose everything. It advises spreading risk.

content.phrase: Dot one's i's and cross one's t's

meanings.english: Be detailed and exact; pay attention to every small detail.
meanings.hindi: बारीकियों का ध्यान रखना / काम पूरा पक्का करना।

content.usage: Make sure you dot your i's and cross your t's before submitting the contract.

extras.mnemonic: Writing neatly requires finishing the letters 'i' and 't' properly.
extras.origin: Handwriting. To write perfectly, you must go back and put a dot on every 'i' and a cross on every 't'. It means paying attention to tiny details.

meanings.english: Without money; destitute; defeated.

content.usage: After losing his job and home, he was down and out.

extras.mnemonic: Boxing: knocked 'down' and counted 'out'.
extras.origin: Boxing. A fighter knocked 'down' and counted 'out' is defeated. It describes someone who has lost everything and is destitute.

meanings.english: Sad and depressed.

content.usage: She has been down in the dumps since she failed the test.

extras.mnemonic: Dumps originally meant a confused state of mind or a melancholy melody.
extras.origin: 16th century. 'Dumps' meant a melancholy tune or a fit of abstraction. Being 'in the dumps' meant being in a sad mood.

meanings.english: Depressed; unhappy.

content.usage: Why are you looking so down in the mouth today?

extras.mnemonic: When sad, the corners of the mouth turn down.
extras.origin: Facial expression. When you are sad, the corners of your mouth turn down. It's a literal description of a sad face.

meanings.english: Wasted or lost.
meanings.hindi: बर्बाद होना / पानी में बह जाना।

content.usage: All our hard work went down the drain when the project was cancelled.

extras.mnemonic: Money/items flushed down a sink drain are gone forever.
extras.origin: Plumbing. Water that goes down the drain is lost forever. It implies wasting money or effort with no recovery.

meanings.english: Be reluctant to do something; act slowly.

content.usage: The government is dragging its feet on the new policy.

extras.mnemonic: Walking by dragging feet is slow and shows lack of energy/will.
extras.origin: Walking. If you don't lift your feet, you drag them, moving slowly and reluctantly. It implies intentional delay.

meanings.english: Be the first to gain an advantage or score against an opponent.
meanings.hindi: पहली जीत हासिल करना / पहला वार करना।

content.usage: Our team drew first blood by scoring a goal in the opening minute.

extras.mnemonic: In fencing/duels, the first person to bleed loses the round.
extras.origin: Fencing/Boxing. The first person to make the opponent bleed draws 'first blood'. It means scoring the first victory in a conflict.

meanings.english: Dressed to attract attention; wearing very glamorous clothes.
meanings.hindi: कहर ढाना (सज-धज कर) / बहुत आकर्षक कपड़े पहनना।

content.usage: She arrived at the party dressed to kill.

extras.mnemonic: Looking so good it 'kills' (stuns) the onlookers.
extras.origin: Slang. Wearing clothes so stunning that they 'kill' (overwhelm) anyone who looks. It implies dressing to impress powerfully.

meanings.english: Scold severely.

content.usage: The boss gave him a dressing down for being late.

extras.mnemonic: Unclear origin, but possibly related to 'dressing' (preparing/punishing) something.
extras.origin: To 'dress' wood or stone is to prepare it by beating/smoothing. A dressing down is a verbal beating or scolding.

meanings.english: Used his imagination.

content.usage: The writer drew on his fancy to create the magical world.

extras.mnemonic: Fancy = Imagination (old usage); Drawing on it = extracting from it.
extras.origin: Literary. 'Fancy' meant imagination. Drawing on your fancy means pulling ideas from your own imagination.

meanings.english: To emphasize a point forcefully so it is understood.
meanings.hindi: बात को जोर देकर समझाना / मनवाना।

content.usage: The teacher used examples to drive home the importance of honesty.

extras.mnemonic: Driving a nail all the way 'home' (into the wood); making the point stick.
extras.origin: Carpentry. To drive a nail 'home' means hammering it all the way in. Metaphorically, making a point understood completely.

meanings.english: Pay a casual visit.

content.usage: Feel free to drop in whenever you are in the neighborhood.

extras.mnemonic: Dropping into a chair/house casually.
extras.origin: Social. To 'drop in' suggests a casual, unplanned arrival, like falling into a chair. It means visiting without an appointment.

meanings.english: Mention famous people to impress others.
meanings.hindi: बड़े लोगों का नाम लेना (प्रभाव जमाना)।

content.usage: He is annoying because he always drops names of movie stars he met once.

extras.mnemonic: Dropping heavy names into conversation to add weight to your status.
extras.origin: Social climbing. Dropping heavy names into a conversation adds weight to your status. It's a way of showing off connections.

meanings.english: Collapsing or dying in large numbers.
meanings.hindi: बड़ी संख्या में मरना या बीमार पड़ना।

content.usage: In the heatwave, people were dropping like flies.

extras.mnemonic: Flies die easily and in large numbers when sprayed.
extras.origin: Agriculture. Flies are fragile and die in masses when sprayed. 'Dropping like flies' describes people collapsing or dying in large numbers.

meanings.english: A keen and enthusiastic person.
meanings.hindi: उत्साही व्यक्ति / काम के लिए उतावला।

content.usage: The new intern is a real eager beaver, arriving early every day.

extras.mnemonic: Beavers are known for working hard (dam building); 'eager' rhymes and fits.
extras.origin: Beavers work incredibly hard building dams. An 'eager beaver' is someone remarkably enthusiastic and hardworking.

meanings.english: To urge or encourage someone to do something foolish or dangerous.

content.usage: He only jumped because his friends egged him on.

extras.mnemonic: Not related to chicken eggs; comes from Norse 'eggja' meaning to edge/incite.
extras.origin: Not related to chicken eggs. From the Old Norse *eggja*, meaning to edge or incite. 'Egging on' means pushing someone to do something.

meanings.english: Hard physical work, especially cleaning or polishing.

content.usage: It will take some elbow grease to get this stain out.

extras.mnemonic: Grease makes things move; moving your elbow (working hard) is the 'grease' needed.
extras.origin: Humorous. Polishing furniture requires vigorous arm movement. 'Elbow grease' jokes that the sweat/effort from the elbow is the polish.

meanings.english: Enough space to move freely.
meanings.hindi: काम करने की जगह / पर्याप्त स्थान।

content.usage: The crowded bus had no elbow room.

extras.mnemonic: Space to stick out your elbows without hitting anyone.
extras.origin: Crowds. If you have elbow room, you can stick your elbows out without hitting anyone. It means having enough space.

meanings.english: An obvious issue left unaddressed due to its sensitivity.
meanings.hindi: एक बड़ी समस्या जिसे सब अनदेखा कर रहे हों।

content.usage: His drinking problem was the elephant in the room at the party.

extras.mnemonic: A huge elephant in a small room is impossible to miss, yet everyone pretends it's not there.
extras.origin: A huge elephant in a tiny room is impossible to miss. If people ignore it, they are actively pretending. It means a huge, ignored problem.

meanings.english: A complete failure.

content.usage: The party ended in a fiasco when the food ran out.

extras.mnemonic: Fiasco is Italian for 'bottle'; likely refers to a glassblowing failure turning into a mere bottle.
extras.origin: Italian glassblowing. If a beautiful glass piece failed, it was set aside as a common flask (*fiasco*). So, a fiasco is a total failure.

meanings.english: Old age.

content.usage: He is enjoying the evening of his life in a quiet village.

extras.mnemonic: Evening is the end of the day; similarly, old age is the end of life.
extras.origin: Poetic. Morning is youth, evening is old age. The 'evening of life' is the final period before the night (death).

meanings.english: Completely a gentleman.

content.usage: He stood up when she entered; he is every inch a gentleman.

extras.mnemonic: Every single inch of his body measures up to the standard.
extras.origin: Measurement. Inspecting every inch of a person. If every inch measures up to the standard, they are 'every inch' a gentleman—completely genuine.

meanings.english: A duplicate or counterpart that acts in a contrary or bad manner.

content.usage: He acts so differently when drunk, like he has an evil twin.

extras.mnemonic: Twin implies lookalike; evil implies bad nature.
extras.origin: Folklore. The doppelgänger or evil twin is a lookalike with a reverse, evil morality. It explains sudden bad behavior.

meanings.english: Something which surprises or offends people.

content.usage: Her bold speech was quite eyebrow raising for the conservative audience.

extras.mnemonic: We raise our eyebrows when shocked or skeptical.
extras.origin: Body language. When shocked or skeptical, people instinctively raise their eyebrows. An 'eyebrow-raising' event is shocking or scandalous.

meanings.english: Timid; lacking courage.

content.usage: This horror movie is not for the faint hearted.

extras.mnemonic: Someone whose heart is weak (faint) and cannot handle stress.
extras.origin: Old proverb: 'Faint heart never won fair lady'. A 'faint' heart is weak and pumps poorly. It describes a timid, cowardly person.

meanings.english: Just treatment; believing that things should be equal.
meanings.hindi: न्याय तो न्याय है / सब बराबर होना चाहिए।

content.usage: I let you drive last time, so it's my turn now. Fair's fair.

extras.mnemonic: Reiteration of fairness.
extras.origin: Colloquial. A tautology used to assert that justice must be served. 'Fair is fair' means rules apply equally to everyone.

meanings.english: To seek support; to rely on something when other things fail.
meanings.hindi: सहारा लेना / अंतिम विकल्प के रूप में प्रयोग करना।

content.usage: If I lose my job, I have my savings to fall back on.

extras.mnemonic: Falling backwards and having something catch you.
extras.origin: Military. If the front line fails, the army 'falls back' to a reserve position. It means relying on a backup plan.

meanings.english: To fail to reach a particular level or standard.

content.usage: The charity event fell short of its goal.

extras.mnemonic: An arrow landing 'short' of the target.
extras.origin: Archery. If an arrow doesn't have enough power, it falls to the ground before reaching the target—it 'falls short'. It means failing to meet a goal.

meanings.english: Falling deeply in love.

content.usage: He is falling head over heels for his new neighbor.

extras.mnemonic: Tumbling continuously (somersault); loss of balance due to love.
extras.origin: Originally 'heels over head' (a cartwheel). It changed to 'head over heels', implying a tumble where you lose balance and control, just like falling in love.

meanings.english: Outcome; result (often negative).

content.usage: The political fallout of the scandal was severe.

extras.mnemonic: Radioactive dust falling out of the sky after a bomb; bad consequences.
extras.origin: Nuclear Physics. After a nuclear explosion, radioactive dust falls out of the sky. 'Fallout' refers to the lingering, negative effects of a disaster.

meanings.english: Quarrel; stop being friendly.

content.usage: They used to be best friends, but they fell out over money.

extras.mnemonic: Falling out of the formation/group.
extras.origin: Military. Soldiers 'fall in' to form a line and 'fall out' to break it. Falling out implies breaking the bond or friendship.

meanings.english: To be very different from.

content.usage: This hotel is a far cry from the luxury resort we expected.

extras.mnemonic: A distance so long that a cry cannot be heard.
extras.origin: Measurement. The distance over which a human cry can be heard. A 'far cry' is a distance too great to shout across—meaning very different.

meanings.english: Make money in an improper way to promote one's own interest.
meanings.hindi: अपनी तिजोरी भरना / बेईमानी से कमाना।

content.usage: The politician was accused of feathering his own nest with public funds.

extras.mnemonic: Birds line their nests with soft feathers to make it comfortable; people make their life comfortable using money.
extras.origin: Nature. Birds line their nests with soft feathers to make them comfortable. A human 'feathering his nest' is making his life comfortable, often greedily.

meanings.english: Feel gloomy or dejected.

content.usage: I always feel blue on rainy days.

extras.mnemonic: Blue is associated with sadness (Blues music, coldness).
extras.origin: Music/Color. Blue is associated with coldness and sadness (the Blues). Feeling blue means feeling sad or depressed.

meanings.english: Find his views; gauge opinion.
meanings.hindi: नब्ज टटोलना / मन की बात जानना।

content.usage: I will talk to the boss to feel his pulse regarding the new idea.

extras.mnemonic: Checking heart rate (pulse) tells you the condition; checking views tells the situation.
extras.origin: Medical. A doctor feels a pulse to check heart health. 'Feeling the pulse' of a group means checking their mood or opinion.

meanings.english: Face financial difficulty.

content.usage: With rising inflation, many families are starting to feel the pinch.

extras.mnemonic: A pinch hurts; tight shoes pinch; lack of money is a painful tightness.
extras.origin: Shoes. If shoes are too tight, they pinch your feet painfully. 'Feeling the pinch' means feeling the pain of financial tightness.

meanings.english: Turn back; retreat.

content.usage: The army had to fall back when they ran out of ammo.

extras.mnemonic: Moving back.
extras.origin: Military. To retreat to a safer position. 'Falling back' means withdrawing from a confrontation.

meanings.english: To get into trouble with; to conflict with.
meanings.hindi: विवाद में पड़ना / नियम विरुद्ध होना।

content.usage: He fell foul of the law by ignoring the regulations.

extras.mnemonic: In sports, a foul is a violation; falling into a foul means being in violation.
extras.origin: Nautical. Ships colliding or getting ropes tangled 'fell foul' of each other. It means getting into conflict or trouble.

meanings.english: Failed (usually a plan).
meanings.hindi: असफल हो जाना / रद्द हो जाना।

content.usage: Our vacation plans fell through because of the storm.

extras.mnemonic: Falling through a hole in the floor implies the support structure failed.
extras.origin: A plan 'falling through' is like falling through a weak floor. The support wasn't there, and the whole thing collapsed.

meanings.english: Avoid encountering; try to avoid.

content.usage: He fights shy of making long-term commitments.

extras.mnemonic: Acting shy and staying away.
extras.origin: Military. Originally meant to lose confidence or be scared. To 'fight shy' means to struggle to avoid or stay away from something.

meanings.english: Beginning to understand the work and feeling confident.
meanings.hindi: जमने की कोशिश करना / आत्मनिर्भर होना।

content.usage: She is new to the job, but she is quickly finding her feet.

extras.mnemonic: A baby learning to stand finds its feet to balance.
extras.origin: Childhood. A toddler learning to walk wobbles until they 'find their feet' and balance. It means gaining confidence in a new job.

meanings.english: Make someone feel very interested and excited.
meanings.hindi: कल्पना शक्ति को उत्तेजित करना / जोश भर देना।

content.usage: The story fired the children's imagination.

extras.mnemonic: Lighting a fire in the mind.
extras.origin: Sparks start a fire. A story that 'fires' the imagination ignites a burning interest and excitement in the mind.

meanings.english: In a perfectly healthy condition.

content.usage: After the surgery, he is now as fit as a fiddle.

extras.mnemonic: Fiddles (violins) need precision tuning ('fit' meant excellent/suitable).
extras.origin: 1600s. 'Fit' meant suitable. A fiddle (violin) must be perfectly tuned ('fit') to play well. Being 'fit as a fiddle' means being in perfect health.

meanings.english: Someone whose success is short-lived; a momentary success.
meanings.hindi: चार दिन की चांदनी / क्षणिक सफलता।

content.usage: His first song was a hit, but he turned out to be a flash in the pan.

extras.mnemonic: In old muskets, if only the priming powder in the pan lit up but didn't fire the bullet, it was a useless flash.
extras.origin: Muskets. Gunpowder in the priming pan might flash but fail to fire the bullet. A 'flash in the pan' is a showy success that yields no real result.

meanings.english: A place where second-hand goods and antiques are sold.

content.usage: We bought this vintage lamp at a flea market.

extras.mnemonic: Old clothes sold there might have fleas.
extras.origin: French: *Marché aux puces*. Old outdoor markets sold second-hand clothes that were often infested with fleas. The name stuck for cheap antique markets.

meanings.english: To puzzle; perplex; confuse (or knock down).

content.usage: The difficult math problem completely floored me.

extras.mnemonic: Knocking someone to the floor (figuratively) with a question.
extras.origin: Boxing. Being knocked to the floor ends the fight. If a question 'floors' you, it defeats you completely—you have no answer.

meanings.english: Become extremely angry suddenly.

content.usage: He flew into a rage when he saw the damage.

extras.mnemonic: Flying suggests sudden, fast movement into anger.
extras.origin: Bird behavior. Birds fly up suddenly when startled. 'Flying into a rage' implies a sudden, upward burst of angry energy.

meanings.english: Change the subject immediately; start discussing something irrelevant.

content.usage: We were discussing budget, but he flew off at a tangent about office coffee.

extras.mnemonic: In geometry, a tangent line touches a circle and goes off in a straight line away from it.
extras.origin: Geometry. A tangent is a line that touches a circle and then goes off straight away from it. It describes leaving the main topic.

meanings.english: Children leaving their parents' home to live on their own.

content.usage: All her children have flown the nest, and the house feels empty.

extras.mnemonic: Birds fly away from the nest when they grow up.
extras.origin: Nature. Young birds must fly from the nest to survive. It describes children growing up and leaving their parents' home.

meanings.english: Suddenly become enraged.
meanings.hindi: आपे से बाहर होना / अचानक गुस्साना।

content.usage: He is known for flying off the handle at the slightest provocation.

extras.mnemonic: If an axe head is loose, it flies off the handle when swung; uncontrolled and dangerous.
extras.origin: Tools. Old axes had loose heads. If swung hard, the head would fly off the handle dangerously. It describes losing control of one's temper.

meanings.english: To do as others have done.

content.usage: When one bank lowered interest rates, the others followed suit.

extras.mnemonic: In card games (like Bridge), you must play a card of the same suit (heart, diamond, etc.) as the previous player.
extras.origin: Card games. In Whist or Bridge, you must play a card of the same suit as the leader. 'Following suit' means copying what someone else does.

meanings.english: Under any circumstances; accepting the results whatever they are.

content.usage: I promised to stay with him for better or worse.

extras.mnemonic: Marriage vows ('for better for worse').
extras.origin: Marriage vows. 'For better for worse, for richer for poorer'. It means staying committed through good times and bad.

meanings.english: Forever; permanently.

content.usage: She decided to leave the city for good.

extras.mnemonic: Short for 'for good and all'.
extras.origin: Short for 'for good and all'. It means the action is final and will last forever.

meanings.english: Forever; to keep permanently.

content.usage: This time, I'm giving you the book for keeps.

extras.mnemonic: To keep something implies not returning it.
extras.origin: Kids' games. In marbles, you could play for fun or 'for keeps'—meaning you keep the marbles you win. It implies permanence.

meanings.english: A short nap during the day.

content.usage: I'll just take forty winks before we go out for dinner.

extras.mnemonic: A wink is closing eyes; 40 implies a short duration (not a full sleep).
extras.origin: Biblical. Forty is a common number for a period (40 days). A 'wink' is a moment of sleep. 'Forty winks' is a short nap.

meanings.english: All the way from the front to the back (completely).
meanings.hindi: पूर्ण रूप से / आगे से पीछे तक।

content.usage: We cleaned the house from stem to stern.

extras.mnemonic: Stem is the front of a ship; Stern is the back.
extras.origin: Nautical. The stem is the front prow; the stern is the rear. From 'stem to stern' means the entire length of the ship—completely.

meanings.english: Full of nonsense; talking a lot without meaning.

content.usage: Don't listen to him; he's full of hot air.

extras.mnemonic: Hot air rises but is empty substance; like a balloon.
extras.origin: Hot air rises but has no substance (like a balloon). A person 'full of hot air' talks a lot but says nothing of value.

meanings.english: Loud and angry words that attract attention but do nothing useful.
meanings.hindi: ऊँची आवाज़ लेकिन सारहीन (थोथा चना बाजे घना)।

content.usage: The debate was full of sound and fury, signifying nothing.

extras.mnemonic: Reference to a noisy storm that passes without impact.
extras.origin: Shakespeare (Macbeth). 'Life... is a tale told by an idiot, full of sound and fury, signifying nothing.' Loud chaos with no meaning.

meanings.english: Move onward with determination and max speed.

content.usage: The project is now full steam ahead.

extras.mnemonic: Steam engines go fastest at full steam pressure.
extras.origin: Steam engines. 'Full steam' means maximum pressure for maximum speed. 'Full steam ahead' is the command to go forward as fast as possible.

meanings.english: Hateful; extremely bitter experience.

content.usage: The defeat was gall and wormwood to the proud general.

extras.mnemonic: Gall is bile (bitter); Wormwood is a bitter plant. Together implies extreme bitterness.
extras.origin: Biblical. Gall is bitter bile; wormwood is a bitter plant. Together they represent the ultimate bitter, hateful experience.

meanings.english: The deception is at an end; the secret is out.

content.usage: The police arrived, and the thief knew the game was up.

extras.mnemonic: When the game ends, you can no longer play/pretend.
extras.origin: Hunting/Gambling. When the hunt is over or the cards are shown, the 'game is up'. The deception is finished and the truth is out.

meanings.english: Uninvited guest.

content.usage: Security removed the gate crasher from the wedding.

extras.mnemonic: Someone who crashes through the gate without a ticket.
extras.origin: 1920s slang. Someone who crashes through the gate without a ticket. It refers to an uninvited guest at a party.

meanings.english: To reveal a secret or the truth unintentionally.

content.usage: He tried to lie, but his nervous expression gave the game away.

extras.mnemonic: If you show your cards during a card game, you give the game away to your opponent.
extras.origin: Hunting/Cards. If a hunter makes noise, the game (animals) run away. If a player shows cards, the game is spoiled. It means revealing a secret.

meanings.english: To express an emotion forcefully.
meanings.hindi: भड़ास निकालना / भावनाओं को व्यक्त करना।

content.usage: She gave vent to her frustration by shouting at the driver.

extras.mnemonic: A vent allows steam or pressure to escape; giving vent allows emotions to escape.
extras.origin: Physics. A vent allows pressurized steam to escape safely. 'Giving vent' to emotions allows pressure to escape before you explode.

meanings.english: To manipulate the boundaries of an electoral constituency to favor one party.
meanings.hindi: चुनाव-क्षेत्रों में हेराफेरी करना (अनुचित लाभ के लिए)।

content.usage: The opposition accused the ruling party of gerrymandering the districts.

extras.mnemonic: Governor Gerry + Salamander (shape of the map he created).
extras.origin: Politics. In 1812, Governor Gerry redrew a map to favor his party. The shape looked like a salamander. Gerry + Salamander = Gerrymander.

content.phrase: Get a foot in the door

meanings.english: To have a chance to do something; to enter a business/organization at a low level.

content.usage: An internship is a great way to get a foot in the door at a big company.

extras.mnemonic: Salesmen used to put a foot in the door so the owner couldn't close it, gaining a chance to talk.
extras.origin: Sales. Door-to-door salesmen would jam a foot in the door so the owner couldn't close it. It bought them a chance to talk.

meanings.english: Earn a merit point for doing well.

content.usage: You get a gold star for finishing your homework early.

extras.mnemonic: Teachers put gold star stickers on good papers.
extras.origin: Education. Teachers traditionally stick gold stars on excellent homework. Getting a gold star means receiving praise for good work.

meanings.english: Start doing something immediately and with energy.

content.usage: We have a lot to do, so let's get cracking.

extras.mnemonic: Cracking a whip to start a horse moving fast.
extras.origin: Wagon driving. 'Get cracking' refers to cracking the whip to get the horses moving. It means to start working immediately.

meanings.english: Start talking about the most important facts or details.
meanings.hindi: असली मुद्दे पर आना / बुनियादी बातों पर चर्चा करना।

content.usage: Stop making small talk and let's get down to brass tacks.

extras.mnemonic: Brass tacks were used to measure fabric exactly on a counter; getting to them meant getting to the real measure.
extras.origin: Upholstery/Drapery. To check fabric length, clerks used brass tacks measured on the counter. Getting down to brass tacks meant getting to the exact facts.

meanings.english: To be in a difficult situation or trouble.

content.usage: He got into a soup by borrowing money from a loan shark.

extras.mnemonic: Being stuck in thick, hot soup would be messy and uncomfortable.
extras.origin: Slang. Fog is sometimes called 'pea soup'. Being in a soup implies being lost in fog or stuck in a thick, messy situation.

content.phrase: Get on like a house on fire

meanings.english: To become friends quickly and have a great relationship.
meanings.hindi: बहुत जल्दी घुल-मिल जाना / गहरी दोस्ती होना।

content.usage: They met yesterday and are getting on like a house on fire.

extras.mnemonic: A fire spreads through a house very rapidly and intensely.
extras.origin: Fire spreads through a house incredibly fast and consumes everything. 'Getting on like a house on fire' means a friendship developing rapidly and intensely.

meanings.english: To annoy or irritate someone.
meanings.hindi: नाक में दम करना / परेशान करना।

content.usage: That loud music is getting on my nerves.

extras.mnemonic: Hitting a raw nerve causes pain/irritation.
extras.origin: Medical. Nerves transmit pain. If something 'gets on your nerves', it irritates you like a dentist drilling on a raw nerve.

content.phrase: Get one's ducks in a row

meanings.english: Have everything properly organized.
meanings.hindi: पूरी तैयारी करना / सब कुछ व्यवस्थित रखना।

content.usage: We need to get our ducks in a row before the presentation.

extras.mnemonic: Mother ducks lead their ducklings in a straight, organized line.
extras.origin: Nature. Mother ducks lead their babies in a perfect straight line. 'Getting ducks in a row' means organizing everything perfectly.

meanings.english: To irritate or annoy someone.

content.usage: It really gets my goat when people cut in line.

extras.mnemonic: Goats were put with racehorses to calm them; stealing the goat would upset the horse.
extras.origin: Horse racing. Goats were put in stables to calm high-strung horses. Rivals would steal the goat to upset the horse. It means annoying someone.

meanings.english: Start doing something; set a process in motion.

content.usage: I'll make the first donation to get the ball rolling.

extras.mnemonic: In sports, the game starts when the ball moves.
extras.origin: Sports. In soccer or croquet, the game begins when the ball is set in motion. 'Getting the ball rolling' means starting the activity.

meanings.english: Learn how to use or do something.
meanings.hindi: किसी काम को करने का तरीका सीख लेना।

content.usage: It took me a while to get the hang of this new software.

extras.mnemonic: Learning how a tool 'hangs' or balances in your hand.
extras.origin: Tools. A tool (like a scythe or bat) must 'hang' or balance correctly in your hand. Getting the hang of it means learning the technique.

meanings.english: To be dismissed from a job.

content.usage: He got the sack for stealing office supplies.

extras.mnemonic: Workmen used to carry tools in a sack; getting the sack back meant you were leaving.
extras.origin: Tradesmen. Mechanics carried their own tools in a sack. If fired, the boss gave them the sack to pack up and leave.

meanings.english: To get an advantage or control.

content.usage: Our team got the upper hand in the second half of the game.

extras.mnemonic: In a hand-over-hand stick game, the person whose hand is on top wins.
extras.origin: Games. In a stick game, players placed hands one above the other. The one whose hand ended on top won. It implies gaining control.

meanings.english: Hear about something secret; suspect something.

content.usage: If the media gets wind of this scandal, we are finished.

extras.mnemonic: Animals smell (get wind of) hunters before seeing them.
extras.origin: Hunting. Animals can smell a hunter if the wind blows the scent to them. 'Getting wind' means catching a hint of something hidden.

meanings.english: Organise your life or work in a better way.
meanings.hindi: अपना काम ठीक से करना / सुधर जाना।

content.usage: You need to get your act together if you want to pass this course.

extras.mnemonic: An actor must know lines and moves (the act) to perform well.
extras.origin: Theater/Circus. A performing troupe's 'act' consists of costumes, lines, and props. Getting it 'together' means organizing everything for a good performance.

meanings.english: Annoying people by interfering or being present.

content.usage: The children were running around getting in everyone's hair.

extras.mnemonic: Like lice or tangles in hair that are irritating and hard to remove.
extras.origin: Lice. Head lice get in your hair and cause constant itching and annoyance. It describes someone who is persistently irritating.

meanings.english: To stay away from someone or something; to avoid.

content.usage: I give that angry dog a wide berth whenever I walk past.

extras.mnemonic: Berth is the space a ship needs to turn/anchor; give a dangerous ship lots of space.
extras.origin: Nautical. A 'berth' is the space a ship needs to swing at anchor. You give a wide berth to dangerous ships to avoid collision.

content.phrase: Give a piece of one's mind

meanings.english: Reprimand; scold angrily.

content.usage: He was so rude that I had to give him a piece of my mind.

extras.mnemonic: Sharing a part of your thoughts (which are angry ones).
extras.origin: Archaic. The mind was seen as a physical substance. Giving someone a 'piece' of it meant sharing your angry thoughts with them.

meanings.english: Compromise; mutual adjustment.

content.usage: Marriage requires a lot of give and take.

extras.mnemonic: You give something and take something; balance.
extras.origin: Negotiation. You give a little, you take a little. It implies mutual compromise and adjustment.

meanings.english: To accept defeat; yield.

content.usage: After hours of arguing, he finally gave in.

extras.mnemonic: Giving your weapon 'in' to the enemy.
extras.origin: Military. Originally 'give in' meant to hand over your weapons or castle keys to the enemy. It means surrendering.

meanings.english: Try something.

content.usage: I've never played golf, but I'll give it a shot.

extras.mnemonic: Taking a 'shot' at a target.
extras.origin: Military/Hunting. Taking a 'shot' is firing a gun at a target. Giving it a shot means making an attempt to hit the goal.

meanings.english: Try out something; attempt.

content.usage: This game looks hard, but let's give it a whirl.

extras.mnemonic: Spinning (whirling) a wheel to see what happens.
extras.origin: Gambling. Spinning (whirling) a wheel or dice. 'Giving it a whirl' means trying your luck.

meanings.english: Pretend to be better than one is; behave arrogantly.

content.usage: Since her promotion, she has started giving herself airs.

extras.mnemonic: Putting on 'airs' means acting lofty/high.
extras.origin: French *air* meant manner or look. Giving yourself 'airs' means putting on a fake, superior manner to impress others.

meanings.english: Deliberately ignore someone; treat unfriendliness.

content.usage: I thought we were friends, but she gave me the cold shoulder at the party.

extras.mnemonic: Serving a guest a 'cold shoulder' of mutton instead of a hot meal was a sign to leave.
extras.origin: Medieval hospitality. A welcome guest got a hot meal. An unwanted guest was given the 'cold shoulder' of mutton—a polite sign to leave.

meanings.english: Call someone on the telephone.

content.usage: I'll give you a ring when I arrive.

extras.mnemonic: Old phones had bells that rang.
extras.origin: Telephones. Old phones had actual bells that rang loudly. 'Giving a ring' meant calling someone.

meanings.english: Die; stop working (for machines).

content.usage: My old car finally gave up the ghost yesterday.

extras.mnemonic: The 'ghost' is the spirit/soul; giving it up means dying.
extras.origin: Biblical. 'Ghost' meant spirit or soul. 'Giving up the ghost' meant the soul leaving the body—death.

meanings.english: Collapse; yield; allow someone to pass.
meanings.hindi: टूट जाना / रास्ता देना / हार मान लेना।

content.usage: The bridge gave way under the heavy load.

extras.mnemonic: Giving the 'way' (path) to something else; or structure letting go.
extras.origin: Engineering. A bridge or floor 'gives way' when the load is too heavy. It implies collapsing or yielding to pressure.

meanings.english: Express anger or frustration.

content.usage: He gnashed his teeth in fury when he lost the game.

extras.mnemonic: Grinding teeth together is a physical sign of suppressed rage.
extras.origin: Biblical. 'Weeping and gnashing of teeth' describes hell's torment. Grinding teeth is a physical sign of suppressed rage or pain.

meanings.english: Something in conflict with one's values or natural instincts.
meanings.hindi: स्वभाव के विरुद्ध / ज़मीर के ख़िलाफ़।

content.usage: Lying to my parents goes against the grain for me.

extras.mnemonic: Rubbing wood against the direction of fibers (grain) is rough and difficult.
extras.origin: Carpentry. Wood is smooth if you rub with the grain, but rough if you go against it. It means doing something unnatural or difficult.

meanings.english: Go bankrupt; fail completely.
meanings.hindi: दिवालिया हो जाना / बंद हो जाना।

content.usage: During the pandemic, many small businesses went belly up.

extras.mnemonic: Dead fish float with their belly up.
extras.origin: Nature. When fish die, they float to the surface belly up. It describes a business or plan that has died completely.

meanings.english: Become crazy or extremely excited/angry.
meanings.hindi: पागल हो जाना / आपे से बाहर हो जाना।

content.usage: The crowd went bonkers when the team scored.

extras.mnemonic: Bonk means hit on the head; getting hit makes you crazy.
extras.origin: British slang. A 'bonk' is a hit on the head. Being 'bonkers' implies you were hit on the head and went crazy.

meanings.english: Fail completely and spectacularly.

content.usage: His presentation went down in flames because he wasn't prepared.

extras.mnemonic: A plane shot down crashes in flames; total destruction.
extras.origin: Aviation. A plane shot down in combat crashes in flames—a total, spectacular disaster. It describes a complete failure.

meanings.english: Divide the cost; pay for oneself.

content.usage: Let's go Dutch on dinner tonight.

extras.mnemonic: Attributed to Dutch customs of thriftiness/sharing.
extras.origin: Anglo-Dutch Wars. The English stereotyped the Dutch as stingy. 'Going Dutch' meant nobody paid for you; you had to pay for yourself.

meanings.english: Use only a small amount of; treat gently.
meanings.hindi: हल्का हाथ रखना / कम इस्तेमाल करना।

content.usage: Go easy on the salt; the soup is already salty.

extras.mnemonic: Being 'easy' or gentle with the supply.
extras.origin: Command. To be 'easy' on something means not to use force. 'Go easy on the sugar' means use it gently/sparingly.

meanings.english: To be sold very cheaply.

content.usage: The antique table went for a song at the auction.

extras.mnemonic: Singing a song is easy/cheap payment compared to money.
extras.origin: Street performers. They would sing a song for a few pennies. Selling something 'for a song' means selling it for a tiny price.

meanings.english: Attack the weakest or most vital part aggressively.
meanings.hindi: कमजोर नस पर वार करना / जानलेवा हमला करना।

content.usage: In the debate, he went for the jugular by attacking his opponent's record.

extras.mnemonic: Jugular vein is vital; cutting it kills instantly.
extras.origin: Animal instinct. Predators bite the jugular vein in the neck to kill instantly. It means attacking the most vulnerable point aggressively.

meanings.english: An ambitious person who actively chases success.

content.usage: We need a go-getter to lead the sales team.

extras.mnemonic: Someone who 'goes' and 'gets' what they want.
extras.origin: Business slang. A 'go-getter' is someone who doesn't wait but goes out and gets success. It implies ambition and action.

meanings.english: Become out of control; stop working correctly.

content.usage: The computer system went haywire after the power surge.

extras.mnemonic: Wire used to bundle hay is springy and tangles easily; chaotic.
extras.origin: Farming. Baling wire (hay wire) is springy and tangles easily. A machine going 'haywire' acts in a tangled, chaotic way.

meanings.english: Explode (bomb); Ring (alarm); Stop liking (food/person).

content.usage: The bomb went off in the market.

extras.mnemonic: Phrasal verb with multiple meanings.
extras.origin: Phrasal verb. Food goes 'off' (bad). Bombs go 'off' (explode). Alarms go 'off' (ring). Context determines the meaning.

meanings.english: Review; examine carefully.

content.usage: Let's go over the details once more.

extras.mnemonic: Going 'over' the surface of something to check it.
extras.origin: Inspection. To go 'over' a surface is to examine it. 'Going over' a document means checking it thoroughly.

meanings.english: Prices rising very high; or becoming very angry.

content.usage: Petrol prices have gone through the roof recently.

extras.mnemonic: Breaking through the roof means going higher than the house limits.
extras.origin: Visual. If a graph line goes straight up, it breaks through the roof. Or, if you explode in anger, you hit the roof. It means extreme rise.

meanings.english: A cemetery (usually beside a church).

content.usage: He was buried in God's acre behind the old chapel.

extras.mnemonic: An acre of land dedicated to God (for the dead).
extras.origin: German *Gottesacker* (God's field). A cemetery is seen as a field 'sown' with bodies waiting for resurrection. It’s a respectful term for a graveyard.

meanings.english: A born fool.

content.usage: Don't listen to him; he acts like God's ape.

extras.mnemonic: An ape mimics humans but isn't one; a natural fool.
extras.origin: Old metaphor. An ape mimics humans but isn't one. A 'God's ape' is a natural fool—someone born simple.

meanings.english: Begin or carry on with an activity.

content.usage: How should we go about solving this problem?

extras.mnemonic: Going around doing things.
extras.origin: Nautical. To 'go about' is to turn the ship to a new tack. It means starting to deal with a task.

meanings.english: Begin to work seriously.

content.usage: Enough chatting, let's get down to business.

extras.mnemonic: Getting serious about the task.
extras.origin: Business. Stop the small talk and focus on the work. It signals the start of serious discussion.

meanings.english: Have a friendly relationship.

content.usage: Despite the age gap, they get on well.

extras.mnemonic: Getting 'on' the same path together.
extras.origin: Travel. Getting 'on' implies boarding a vehicle together. Getting on well means travelling smoothly together in life.

meanings.english: Smile broadly because of happiness.

content.usage: He was grinning from ear to ear after winning the lottery.

extras.mnemonic: A smile so wide it seems to touch both ears.
extras.origin: Visual. A huge smile stretches the mouth so wide it looks like it reaches from one ear to the other.

meanings.english: Should; ought to (strong advice/warning).

content.usage: You had better leave now before the rain starts.

extras.mnemonic: It would be 'better' if you 'had' done this.
extras.origin: Grammar. Short for 'it would be better if you had'. It is a strong recommendation or warning.

content.phrase: Not have a leg to stand on

meanings.english: To have no evidence or logic to support one's argument.

content.usage: Without a receipt, you don't have a leg to stand on for a refund.

extras.mnemonic: A stool needs legs to stand; an argument needs proof.
extras.origin: Furniture. A stool needs legs to stand. Without a leg, it collapses. An argument with no proof 'has no leg to stand on' and fails.

meanings.english: Strong and healthy (especially of old people).

content.usage: At 80, he is still hale and hearty.

extras.mnemonic: Hale = Whole/Healthy.
extras.origin: Old English. 'Hale' means whole or healthy. 'Hale and hearty' emphasizes complete physical robustness, especially in old age.

meanings.english: Together; closely connected.

content.usage: Poverty and crime often go hand in hand.

extras.mnemonic: Holding hands signifies unity.
extras.origin: Visual. People holding hands walk together. It means two things that are closely connected and happen together.

meanings.english: Treat someone with extreme care or delicacy.
meanings.hindi: सावधानी और नरमी से पेश आना।

content.usage: He is very sensitive, so handle him with kid gloves.

extras.mnemonic: Kid gloves are made of soft baby goat leather; used for delicate tasks.
extras.origin: Fashion. Kid gloves are made from the soft skin of a baby goat (kid). They are used for delicate tasks. It means treating someone gently.

meanings.english: Easily and without doubt.

content.usage: This is hands down the best burger I've ever eaten.

extras.mnemonic: A jockey winning a race easily can put his hands down and relax.
extras.origin: Horse racing. If a jockey is winning easily, he can relax his grip and put his 'hands down'. It implies an easy victory.

meanings.english: Listen very carefully.

content.usage: The audience hung on his every word.

extras.mnemonic: Metaphorically holding onto words so none drop.
extras.origin: Visual. Imagine hanging onto a cliff; you hold tight. Hanging on someone's words means listening so intently you don't want to drop a single one.

meanings.english: To be ashamed.

content.usage: He hung his head in shame after admitting the lie.

extras.mnemonic: Looking down avoids eye contact, a sign of shame.
extras.origin: Body language. Shame or guilt makes a person look down, literally 'hanging' their head.

meanings.english: Take retirement (especially from sports).
meanings.hindi: संन्यास लेना / खेल से रिटायर होना।

content.usage: The cricketer decided to hang up his boots after the World Cup.

extras.mnemonic: Hanging boots on the wall because you won't wear them anymore.
extras.origin: Sports. When a player retires, they hang their boots on a peg because they won't need them anymore.

meanings.english: In a dangerous or precarious situation.
meanings.hindi: नाजुक हालत में होना / डोर पर लटकना।

content.usage: After the scandal, his career is hanging by a thread.

extras.mnemonic: Sword of Damocles hung by a single horsehair; very fragile.
extras.origin: Sword of Damocles. The sword hung by a single horsehair. If the thread broke, he died. It means being in imminent danger.

meanings.english: To be deaf or partially deaf.

content.usage: Speak louder, he is hard of hearing.

extras.mnemonic: Hearing is hard (difficult) for them.
extras.origin: Euphemism. 'Hard' means difficult. For this person, the act of hearing is difficult. A polite way to say deaf.

content.phrase: Have a bee in one's bonnet

meanings.english: To be obsessed with an idea; to keep talking about something repeatedly.
meanings.hindi: धुन सवार होना / किसी बात को बार-बार दोहराना।

content.usage: She has a bee in her bonnet about healthy eating.

extras.mnemonic: A bee trapped under a hat (bonnet) buzzes constantly and annoys the wearer; like an obsessive thought.
extras.origin: A bee trapped under a hat (bonnet) buzzes frantically. The wearer can't stop thinking about it. It means being obsessed with an idea.

meanings.english: To scold or criticize severely.

content.usage: The manager hauled him over the coals for missing the deadline.

extras.mnemonic: Dragging someone over hot coals was a medieval torture/ordeal.
extras.origin: Medieval ordeal. Heretics were dragged over red-hot coals to test or punish them. It means giving someone a severe scolding.

meanings.english: To have a grievance or issue to discuss/argue.

content.usage: I have a bone to pick with you regarding the broken window.

extras.mnemonic: A dog picking a bone implies focus and chewing; focusing on a problem.
extras.origin: Dogs chewing bones. 'Having a bone to pick' means you have a difficult issue to chew over (discuss) with someone.

content.phrase: Have a chip on one's shoulder

meanings.english: To hold a grudge; be angry about perceived unfair treatment.
meanings.hindi: मन में कड़वाहट रखना / गुस्से में रहना।

content.usage: He has had a chip on his shoulder ever since he didn't get the promotion.

extras.mnemonic: Boys used to place a wood chip on their shoulder and dare others to knock it off to start a fight.
extras.origin: American custom. Boys dared others to fight by placing a wood chip on their shoulder. Knocking it off started the fight. It implies looking for trouble.

content.phrase: Have a foot in the grave

meanings.english: To be near death or very old.

content.usage: He looks so sick, as if he has one foot in the grave.

extras.mnemonic: Standing at the edge of a grave, almost falling in.
extras.origin: Visual. A person standing at the edge of a grave, one foot already inside. It describes someone very old or near death.

meanings.english: To be good at gardening.

content.usage: Look at her beautiful garden; she really has green fingers.

extras.mnemonic: Handling plants makes fingers green from chlorophyll.
extras.origin: Gardening. Rubbing algae or chlorophyll from plants stains fingers green. A good gardener constantly handles plants, hence 'green fingers'.

meanings.english: To be victorious at the end of an argument or competition.

content.usage: They mocked him, but he had the last laugh when he won the award.

extras.mnemonic: Laughing at the end is the only laugh that matters.
extras.origin: Proverb. 'He who laughs last, laughs longest.' Early winners might lose in the end. The final victory is what counts.

meanings.english: To have more important work to do.

content.usage: I can't stay for tea; I have other fish to fry.

extras.mnemonic: Cooking (frying) fish is a task; having other fish means other tasks.
extras.origin: Cooking. If you have other fish to fry, you have other work to do. You can't waste time on the current matter.

meanings.english: To want something very much.
meanings.hindi: दिल से चाहना / धुन सवार होना।

content.usage: She has her heart set on going to Paris.

extras.mnemonic: Setting your heart (desire) firmly on an object.
extras.origin: Navigation. Setting a course. Having your heart 'set' on something means your desire is fixed on that destination.

meanings.english: To be fond of someone or something; feel affection.

content.usage: Grandpa has a soft spot for his youngest grandchild.

extras.mnemonic: A 'soft' spot is tender and yielding to pressure (affection).
extras.origin: Anatomy/Metaphor. A 'soft spot' is vulnerable and yields to pressure. Having a soft spot for someone means you can't be hard on them.

content.phrase: He who laughs last laughs loudest

meanings.english: The person who wins in the long term is the real winner.
meanings.hindi: अंत भला तो सब भला / असली जीत आखिरी जीत होती है।

content.usage: They are winning now, but remember, he who laughs last laughs loudest.

extras.mnemonic: Proverb indicating patience leads to final victory.
extras.origin: Proverb. Immediate success doesn't matter. The person who wins the final game celebrates the loudest.

meanings.english: Daydreaming; cut off from reality.
meanings.hindi: हवाई किले बनाना / वास्तविकता से दूर।

content.usage: He's not paying attention; he has his head in the clouds.

extras.mnemonic: Clouds are high up; being there means you aren't grounded.
extras.origin: Visual. Clouds are high above reality. Having your head in the clouds means you are daydreaming and not paying attention to earth.

meanings.english: Deeply in love.

content.usage: They met last week and are already head over heels in love.

extras.mnemonic: Tumbling (somersault) completely out of control.
extras.origin: Originally 'heels over head' (a cartwheel). It reversed to 'head over heels', implying a tumble where you lose control, like in love.

meanings.english: People will be punished or fired.

content.usage: If the project fails, heads will roll in the management.

extras.mnemonic: Refers to beheading (execution); losing one's head/job.
extras.origin: Execution. Beheading was a punishment for failure. 'Heads will roll' means people will be fired or punished for a mistake.

meanings.english: Feel sorrow or sympathy for.

content.usage: My heart goes out to the families of the victims.

extras.mnemonic: Sending your heart (love/care) to someone.
extras.origin: Empathy. You feel your heart leaving your body to join the suffering person. It expresses deep sympathy.

meanings.english: Delay; or to rob.

content.usage: Sorry I'm late; I was held up in traffic.

extras.mnemonic: Holding something up stops it from moving forward.
extras.origin: Travel. A highwayman would say 'Hold up!' to stop a coach. Now it means a delay or a robbery.

meanings.english: In disorderly haste; confused and hurried.

content.usage: People ran helter-skelter when the alarm rang.

extras.mnemonic: Rhyming phrase implying chaos.
extras.origin: Rhyme. A reduplication implying haste and confusion. Running 'helter-skelter' is running in a disorganized panic.

meanings.english: Everywhere.

content.usage: I searched high and low for my keys.

extras.mnemonic: Searching high places and low places covering all space.
extras.origin: Geography. Searching the high places (mountains) and low places (valleys). It means searching everywhere.

meanings.english: Arrogant; behaving as if superior.

content.usage: She acts all high and mighty now that she's rich.

extras.mnemonic: Being 'high' above others leads to arrogance.
extras.origin: Social class. 'High' status and 'mighty' power. Used ironically, it describes someone who acts arrogant and superior.

meanings.english: Overbearing; using power without considering others.

content.usage: The employees resented the manager's high-handed decisions.

extras.mnemonic: A hand raised high to strike or command forcefully.
extras.origin: Sword fighting. A blow from a 'high hand' (raised arm) is overpowering. It describes using power arrogantly without consulting others.

meanings.english: To live luxuriously.

content.usage: After winning the lottery, they are living high on the hog.

extras.mnemonic: The best meat (loin/ham) comes from the upper part (high) of the pig (hog).
extras.origin: Butchery. The best meat (loin, ham) is on the upper part ('high') of the pig ('hog'). Poor people ate the feet/belly. Living high on the hog means eating the best.

meanings.english: Became very frightened.
meanings.hindi: खून जम जाना (डर से) / भयभीत होना।

content.usage: His blood ran cold when he saw the ghost.

extras.mnemonic: Fear causes blood vessels to constrict, making you feel cold.
extras.origin: Physiology. Fear constricts blood vessels, making skin cold and pale. 'Blood running cold' describes the physical chill of terror.

meanings.english: Reach a situation that leads to nothing further.
meanings.hindi: ऐसी स्थिति में आना जहाँ से आगे का रास्ता बंद हो।

content.usage: Our investigation has hit a dead end.

extras.mnemonic: A street closed at one end.
extras.origin: Piping/Roads. A pipe or road that is capped off has a 'dead end'. It means reaching a point where no progress is possible.

meanings.english: Explode in anger.
meanings.hindi: आग बबूला होना / गुस्से से उछल पड़ना।

content.usage: Dad hit the ceiling when I crashed the car.

extras.mnemonic: Jumping up in anger so high you hit the roof.
extras.origin: Physics. Heat rises. Extreme anger makes you explode upwards, hitting the ceiling.

content.phrase: Hit the nail on the head

meanings.english: Say or do something exactly right.

content.usage: You hit the nail on the head with your analysis.

extras.mnemonic: Hammering a nail perfectly requires hitting the head exactly.
extras.origin: Carpentry. You must hit the nail exactly on the head to drive it in. It means saying or doing exactly the right thing.

meanings.english: No real choice at all; take it or leave it.
meanings.hindi: कोई विकल्प न होना (सिर्फ एक ही विकल्प)।

content.usage: It's Hobson's choice; either we accept the pay cut or we get fired.

extras.mnemonic: Thomas Hobson (stable owner) offered customers the horse nearest the door or none at all.
extras.origin: History. Thomas Hobson (1600s) rented horses. You had to take the one nearest the door or none. 'Hobson's choice' is no real choice at all.

meanings.english: Meaningless talk designed to trick; nonsense.

content.usage: I don't believe in that astrological hocus pocus.

extras.mnemonic: Magic spell words used by magicians to distract.
extras.origin: Magic. 'Hocus pocus' sounds like a Latin spell (possibly mocking the Catholic mass). It refers to trickery or nonsense.

meanings.english: Endure a difficult situation; refuse to yield.

content.usage: The troops held out against the enemy for weeks.

extras.mnemonic: Holding your position outward against pressure.
extras.origin: Defense. Holding your hand or shield 'out' to stop the enemy. It means resisting pressure.

meanings.english: To be proud; to have self-respect.

content.usage: After your honest work, you can hold up your head anywhere.

extras.mnemonic: Shame makes you lower your head; pride makes you hold it up.
extras.origin: Posture. Shame makes you look down. Pride allows you to hold your head up high. It means maintaining dignity.

meanings.english: To be valid or sound (usually an argument).

content.usage: His excuse doesn't hold water.

extras.mnemonic: A bucket with holes cannot hold water; a flawed argument cannot hold truth.
extras.origin: Pottery. A pot with cracks cannot hold water. A weak argument with 'holes' in it 'does not hold water'.

meanings.english: Nurture hope even when the situation looks impossible.

content.usage: They hoped against hope that the rescuers would find survivors.

extras.mnemonic: Hoping even when 'hope' (logic) says otherwise.
extras.origin: Biblical (Romans 4:18). Abraham 'against hope believed in hope'. It means hoping even when logic says there is no hope.

meanings.english: Behave in a silly and noisy way.

content.usage: Stop horsing around and do your homework.

extras.mnemonic: Young horses (colts) play roughly.
extras.origin: Animal behavior. Horses (especially young ones) are energetic and playful. 'Horsing around' means rough, noisy play.

meanings.english: Common sense; practical wisdom.

content.usage: He may not be educated, but he has a lot of horse sense.

extras.mnemonic: Horses are smart, practical animals.
extras.origin: Old West. Horses were considered smart enough to find their way home. 'Horse sense' is basic, practical wisdom.

meanings.english: Different people are suited for different jobs.
meanings.hindi: जैसा काम वैसा आदमी / हर काम के लिए उपयुक्त व्यक्ति।

content.usage: I wouldn't hire an artist to do accounting; it's horses for courses.

extras.mnemonic: Certain horses run better on certain racecourses (wet/dry/flat).
extras.origin: Racing. Some horses run better on wet tracks, some on dry. 'Horses for courses' means choosing the right person for the specific job.

meanings.english: Noisy expression of public anger or alarm.

content.usage: There was a great hue and cry about the new taxes.

extras.mnemonic: Hue (shout) and Cry (call); a public outcry to catch a criminal.
extras.origin: Legal (13th century). 'Hue' meant shout. 'Hue and cry' was the public shout to chase a criminal. It means a loud public protest.

meanings.english: To save; to use economically.
meanings.hindi: किफायत से खर्च करना / बचत करना।

content.usage: We must husband our resources to survive the winter.

extras.mnemonic: Husband originally meant 'house-bound' or manager of the house; implying careful management.
extras.origin: Old English. 'Husband' meant the master of the house, who had to manage stores carefully. To 'husband' is to use resources thriftily.

meanings.english: Something that makes a good situation even better.

content.usage: The promotion was great, but the bonus was the icing on the cake.

extras.mnemonic: Cake is good; sweet icing on top makes it perfect.
extras.origin: Baking. A cake is good, but icing makes it beautiful and sweet. 'Icing on the cake' is an extra benefit to something already good.

content.phrase: If it's not one thing, it's another

meanings.english: When things keep going wrong one after another.

content.usage: First the car broke, now the roof leaks. If it's not one thing, it's another.

extras.mnemonic: A series of unfortunate events.
extras.origin: Colloquial. A complaint about a series of problems. As soon as one is fixed, another appears.

meanings.english: Uncomfortable; worried.

content.usage: He felt ill at ease in the fancy restaurant.

extras.mnemonic: Not at ease = ill (badly) at ease.
extras.origin: Social. Ease means comfort. Being 'ill' (badly) at ease means feeling uncomfortable or anxious in a situation.

meanings.english: Well informed; involved in current affairs or events.
meanings.hindi: ताज़ा जानकारी रखना / सक्रिय रूप से शामिल।

content.usage: After being away for a month, it took a while to get back in the swim.

extras.mnemonic: Fish in the swim (current) move with the flow; those out of it are left behind.
extras.origin: Fishing. Fish swim in schools. If you are 'in the swim', you are in the main current with everyone else—active and informed.

meanings.english: In a confused, nervous, or excited state.

content.usage: The bride was in a flutter just before the ceremony.

extras.mnemonic: Like a bird fluttering its wings nervously.
extras.origin: Birds. A bird flaps (flutters) its wings rapidly when scared. Being 'in a flutter' describes a state of nervous excitement.

meanings.english: In a difficult situation or trouble.

content.usage: I forgot my wallet at home and now I am in a pickle.

extras.mnemonic: Being preserved in vinegar (pickle) is an uncomfortable state for a vegetable.
extras.origin: Culinary. Vegetables in a pickle jar are preserved in acid—a tight, sour situation. Being 'in a pickle' means being in a difficult spot.

meanings.english: In debt or financial difficulty.

content.usage: Bad investments left him in Queer Street.

extras.mnemonic: Queer meant 'strange' or 'bad'; being on this street meant trouble.
extras.origin: London. Carey Street (where the bankruptcy court was) was nicknamed Queer Street because living there felt strange/wrong. It means financial ruin.

meanings.english: In a difficult situation that is hard to escape.

content.usage: His resignation put the team in a tight corner.

extras.mnemonic: Being cornered with no room to move.
extras.origin: Boxing. If a boxer is trapped in a corner, he can't move or escape. Being in a 'tight corner' means having no easy way out.

meanings.english: Not suitable; offensive or vulgar.

content.usage: His jokes about the funeral were in bad taste.

extras.mnemonic: Just as bad food tastes awful, bad comments feel awful to hear.
extras.origin: Aesthetics. Just as bad food leaves a bad taste in the mouth, a vulgar joke offends the social 'palate'.

meanings.english: In an alliance or conspiracy (usually negative).

content.usage: The police suspected the judge was in cahoots with the mob.

extras.mnemonic: Cahoots sounds like 'co-hoots' (owls hooting together).
extras.origin: French *cahute* (cabin). Living in the same small cabin implied a close partnership. 'In cahoots' implies conspiring together.

meanings.english: Cruelly and deliberately; without emotion.

content.usage: The crime was committed in cold blood.

extras.mnemonic: Hot blood implies passion/anger; cold blood implies calculation and lack of feeling.
extras.origin: Medical history. It was believed that hot blood meant passion, and cold blood meant calculation. Killing 'in cold blood' implies no emotion.

meanings.english: In great difficulty or trouble.

content.usage: He found himself in deep water after lying to the IRS.

extras.mnemonic: If you can't swim, deep water is dangerous.
extras.origin: Swimming. If you can't swim, deep water is terrifying. Being 'in deep water' means facing trouble beyond your ability to handle.

meanings.english: In a very bad or difficult situation.
meanings.hindi: नाजुक हालात में / घोर संकट में।

content.usage: The company is in dire straits and might close soon.

extras.mnemonic: A strait is a narrow water passage; difficult to navigate. Dire means terrible.
extras.origin: Geography. A strait is a narrow channel of water (like Gibraltar). Navigating it is dangerous ('dire'). It means a desperate situation.

meanings.english: In trouble or disfavor.

content.usage: I'm in Dutch with the boss for missing the meeting.

extras.mnemonic: Historical English rivalry with the Dutch led to negative phrases (Dutch courage, Dutch treat).
extras.origin: Anglo-Dutch Wars. The English used 'Dutch' to mean anything bad or fake. Being 'in Dutch' meant being in trouble.

meanings.english: At the height of activity.

content.usage: The party was in full swing when we arrived.

extras.mnemonic: A swing moving at its highest arc is in 'full swing'.
extras.origin: Playground. A swing needs time to reach its maximum height. When it does, it is 'in full swing'. It means activity is at its peak.
